Some sessions, you make breakthroughs. You understand why you react the way you do, why Alex shuts down during conflict, why communication feels impossible sometimes. You learn tools: active listening, 'I' statements, how to fight fair.

Other sessions, you wonder why you're bothering. The problems feel insurmountable. You're too different, too damaged, too far gone. You watch other couples break up in the waiting room and wonder if you're next.

But you keep showing up. Week after week, month after month. Slowly, things shift. Not perfectly. Not magically. But shift nonetheless. You learn Alex's triggers. Alex learns yours. You develop a shared language for navigating rough waters.

Three years later, you're still together. Still in therapy, actually - now it's monthly maintenance instead of weekly crisis management. Your relationship isn't perfect. You still fight sometimes. But you fight better. You repair faster. You know how to come back to each other.
Someone asks if therapy 'fixed' you. You laugh. 'We didn't need fixing. We needed tools. And time. And the willingness to be uncomfortable long enough to grow.'
It's not the ending you imagined, but it's the ending you earned. And that means something.
THE END

bittersweet-ending.title: Different Kinds of Love
story: You remain friends with Alex. Not immediately - there's too much heartbreak for that. But eventually, after time and distance and new relationships heal the raw edges, you find your way back to each other as friends.

It's strange at first. Loving someone but not being in love with them. Caring about their happiness even though it doesn't include you. But it's also freeing. You can appreciate Alex without the pressure of romance. You can support their dreams without sacrificing your own.

You attend Alex's wedding. They attend yours years later. Your partners know the history and aren't threatened by it. That's how you know you've found the right people - they understand that your past with Alex shaped you into who you are now.

Sometimes you wonder about the alternate timeline where it worked out. Where you both bent enough to stay together without breaking. But mostly, you're grateful. Grateful for what you had. Grateful for what you learned. Grateful that love can evolve into something new instead of curdling into bitterness.

On a random Tuesday, Alex texts you a meme that makes you laugh until you cry. You send back a gif. No heavy conversation, no rehashing the past. Just two people who once loved each other romantically and now love each other differently.
It's not the ending you wanted, but it's an ending you can live with. And sometimes, that's the best we can hope for.
THE END

new-york-apartment-choice.title: Finding Home
story: The real estate agent shows you three options, each within your budget but offering different tradeoffs.
Option A: Hell's Kitchen studio. Tiny but walkable to Alex's office. You'd see each other more, but barely have space to breathe. $3,200/month.
Option B: Brooklyn one-bedroom. Actual space, a real kitchen, but Alex would have a 45-minute commute each way. More room to grow, less time together. $2,800/month.
Option C: Queens two-bedroom. Affordable, spacious, but far from everything. You'd have space for guests and a home office, but Alex would spend 2 hours commuting daily. $2,400/month.

options.text: Hell's Kitchen studio - Prioritize proximity to Alex's work and seeing each other daily
Brooklyn one-bedroom - Balance space and commute time
Queens two-bedroom - Prioritize space and savings, even if it means less time together

new-york-apartment-hells-kitchen.title: Cozy in Hell's Kitchen
story: You sign the lease on the Hell's Kitchen studio. 450 square feet of exposed brick and possibility. Alex can walk to work in fifteen minutes. You'll see each other every morning and evening. That matters more than space.

Moving day is chaos. Boxes everywhere, a U-Haul double-parked, your new landlord yelling about blocking the loading zone. The apartment is even smaller than you remembered. Your bed takes up half the room. There's barely space to think, let alone breathe.

But when you finally collapse on the air mattress that night - your furniture won't arrive until tomorrow - Alex pulls you close and whispers, 'We did it. We're really here.' Through the window, the Manhattan skyline glitters like a promise.
Close quarters mean you'll be in each other's space constantly. That could be romantic or suffocating, depending on how you handle it.

options.text: Continue

new-york-apartment-brooklyn.title: Brooklyn Bound
story: You choose the Brooklyn one-bedroom. It's a compromise - not too big, not too small, not too close, not too far. The apartment has hardwood floors, a real kitchen, and windows that actually let in light. You can picture a life here.

Moving day is exhausting but manageable. The movers complain about the three-floor walkup, but once everything's inside, it feels like home. You have a bedroom separate from your living space. You have room to breathe.

Alex does the math on their commute: 45 minutes each way, assuming the subway cooperates. An hour and a half out of every day, gone. 'But look at this place,' they say, spinning around in the empty living room. 'Totally worth it.'

That night, you collapse on the air mattress in your actual bedroom. Through the window, you can hear the neighborhood - conversations in multiple languages, music from a nearby bar, the rumble of the subway. This is Brooklyn. This could be home.

options.text: Continue

new-york-apartment-queens.title: Space in Queens
story: You pick the Queens two-bedroom. It's practical. You'll have a home office for your remote work. Space for friends to visit. Room to grow. The money you save can go toward experiences instead of rent.

Moving day is surprisingly smooth. The movers love the elevator, the super is friendly, and the apartment is even bigger than the photos suggested. You have a second bedroom! A real dining area! Closet space!
But as Alex maps out their commute - subway to subway to walking - the reality sets in. Two hours a day. Ten hours a week. That's a part-time job spent underground, just to get to their actual job.

'It's fine,' Alex says, but you can see them doing the math in their head, calculating what they're giving up. 'We have space. That's what matters.' But you both know they're paying the price for that space.
That night, lying on the air mattress in your spacious bedroom, you wonder if you made the right choice. The silence is nice. But will you feel this far apart in other ways too?

options.text: Continue

new-york-first-morning.title: The First Morning
story: Your first morning in New York. Alex's alarm goes off at 6:30 AM. They fumble for their phone, silencing it quickly. You feel them trying to slip out of bed without waking you.
You're awake though. You've been awake since 6:00, listening to the unfamiliar sounds of your new city. Car horns. Sirens. Someone yelling in a language you don't recognize. This is home now.

Alex is moving quietly around the apartment, getting ready for their first day. You can tell they're nervous. Excited, but nervous. This job, this city, this whole move - it's all about to become real.

options.text: Get up and make breakfast together. Start your first day as a team.
Pretend to sleep. Let Alex have this morning to themselves to focus.
Get up but stay quiet. Make coffee and be supportive without being intrusive.

new-york-breakfast-together.title: Together at Dawn
story: You sit up. 'I'm awake. Want me to make coffee?' Alex's face lights up. 'Really? You don't have to—' 'I want to,' you say. And you do.

You make coffee in your new kitchen. It's terrible - you haven't figured out the machine yet and the water tastes weird. But you sit together on boxes that should be holding dishes, sipping bad coffee, and it feels perfect.
'I'm nervous,' Alex admits. 'What if I'm not good enough? What if I made a mistake taking this job?' You take their hand. 'You're going to be amazing. And I'm right here, no matter what.'
Alex leaves at 7:15, kiss goodbye at the door, promising to text throughout the day. You watch them disappear down the street and feel... proud. Scared, but proud. You're doing this together.

options.text: Continue

new-york-pretend-sleep.title: The Easy Lie
story: You keep your eyes closed. Your breathing slow and steady. You hear Alex moving carefully, trying not to disturb you. The coffee maker. The closet door. The bathroom fan. All the sounds of someone trying to be considerate.

Part of you wants to get up. To wish them luck on their first day. To be the supportive partner. But another part of you is overwhelmed. This city, this apartment, this new life. You need a few more minutes of not having to be okay.
The apartment door closes softly. Alex is gone. You open your eyes to an empty room in an unfamiliar place. You're alone in New York City. Day one of what might be a very long adventure.
You lie there for another twenty minutes before forcing yourself to get up. The apartment feels bigger and lonelier without Alex in it.

options.text: Continue

new-york-quiet-support.title: Silent Partnership
story: You get up quietly and start the coffee maker. Alex comes out of the bathroom, surprised. 'Hey, you're up.' You smile. 'Couldn't sleep anyway. New city sounds.'

You move around each other in the small space. Not talking much, but comfortable in the silence. You hand Alex coffee. They nod thanks. There's an understanding between you - we're in this together, but we both need to process it in our own way.

'Big day,' you finally say. 'Huge day,' Alex agrees. They grab their bag, kiss your cheek. 'I'll text you.' And then they're gone, and you're left with your coffee and an entire day in a brand new city.
You watch them from the window until they turn the corner. Then you turn back to the apartment full of unpacked boxes. Time to figure out who you are in New York.

options.text: Continue

new-york-first-day-alone.title: Day One: Solo
story: The apartment is quiet. Too quiet. You're surrounded by boxes and the weight of what you've just done. You left your job, your friends, your entire life to follow Alex to New York. It was the right decision. You keep telling yourself it was the right decision.
Your phone buzzes. Alex: 'Office is INSANE. Good insane. Corner office has a view of the Chrysler Building! How's unpacking?' You look around at the disaster zone. You haven't unpacked a single box.
You have two weeks before your remote work starts. Two weeks to figure out how to be a New Yorker. Two weeks to prove to yourself - and maybe to Alex - that you belong here.

options.text: Unpack and organize. Make this place feel like home before Alex gets back.
Get out and explore. The boxes can wait - you need to see your new city.
Call someone from home. You need a familiar voice right now.

new-york-unpack-organize.title: Nesting
story: You attack the boxes like they're the enemy. Books on shelves. Clothes in drawers. Kitchen stuff in cabinets. Every item you unpack is a small victory against the chaos. By 4 PM, the apartment looks almost livable.
Your back hurts. You're covered in dust. But when Alex texts 'Leaving office, be home around 7,' you feel a surge of pride. You've been productive. You've built something today.

When Alex walks in at 7:15, exhausted and exhilarated, they stop in the doorway. 'Whoa. You did all this?' You shrug like it's no big deal, but it is. You've turned four walls into a home. That counts for something.

options.text: Continue

new-york-explore-city.title: Urban Explorer
story: You leave the boxes. They'll still be there tomorrow. You grab your phone, your wallet, and your sense of adventure. Time to meet New York.

You wander without a plan. Find the nearest bodega. Get a coffee that costs twice what it should. Walk until your feet hurt. The High Line. Washington Square Park. You get lost three times. It's perfect.
By the time Alex texts 'Leaving office, be home around 7,' you're exhausted but energized. You've walked 23,000 steps according to your phone. You've seen your new city. You've claimed it as yours.
When Alex comes home to an apartment still full of boxes, they don't say anything. They just ask about your day, and you have stories to tell. That feels more important than organized closets.

options.text: Continue

new-york-call-home.title: Lifeline
story: You call your best friend back home. They answer on the second ring. 'How's the big city?' And just like that, you're crying. Not sad crying. Overwhelmed crying. 'It's so much,' you say. 'I know,' they say. 'But you've got this.'

You talk for two hours. About Alex's new job. About the apartment. About your fears that you've made a mistake, that you don't belong here, that you're just the person who tagged along. Your friend listens and reminds you of who you are.

When you hang up, it's 4 PM and you haven't unpacked a single box. But you feel more grounded. Sometimes you need to hear a voice that knows the old you to remember that the new you is still in there somewhere.
Alex texts at 6:45. 'Leaving office! Can't wait to hear about your day.' You look around at the boxes. Maybe tomorrow.

options.text: Continue

new-york-first-week.title: Week One
story: The first week has a rhythm. Alex leaves at 7 AM. You wake up alone in a city that doesn't know your name. Alex comes home at 7 PM, exhausted but electric with new-job energy. They tell you about meetings, projects, the free lunch catering. You tell them about... what?

By Friday, you've figured out the subway. Located the nearest Target. Found a decent bodega where the owner calls you 'friend' even though you've only been there three times. Small victories that feel both significant and pathetically small.

Friday night, Alex comes home with an announcement. 'The team wants to grab drinks after work next Friday. You should come. Meet everyone. See my office.' There's something in their voice - eagerness mixed with nerves. Like they want to show you off but are also worried you won't fit in.
You have a week to decide how you want to show up to that.

options.text: Enthusiastically agree. You want to meet Alex's new world.
Agree but feel nervous. You're not sure you're ready for this.
Suggest maybe next time. You need more time to settle in first.

new-york-week-two-excited.title: Ready to Shine
story: The second week flies by. You spend it preparing - mentally rehearsing small talk, planning your outfit, looking up Alex's company online so you sound informed. You want to make a good impression. You want Alex to be proud to introduce you.

You practice saying things like 'I'm transitioning my career remotely' instead of 'I don't have a job yet.' You prepare anecdotes that make you sound interesting and accomplished. You're determined to be the partner who enhances Alex's reputation, not the one who drags it down.
By Friday, you're as ready as you'll ever be. Alex seems excited that you're excited. 'Everyone's going to love you,' they promise. You hope they're right.

options.text: Continue

new-york-week-two-nervous.title: The Weight of Expectations
story: The second week is spent anxious. You keep thinking about that happy hour. What if you don't fit in? What if Alex's colleagues are all Type-A corporate climbers and you're just... you? What if they wonder why Alex brought their tagalong partner to a work event?

You try to distract yourself. Unpack more boxes. Walk through different neighborhoods. Start looking at job postings even though you have two weeks before your remote work begins. Anything to not think about Friday.
But Friday comes anyway. Alex bounces through the door Wednesday evening: 'Can't wait for you to meet everyone!' Your stomach twists. But you smile. 'Me too.'
You're doing this. You're going to show up and be supportive and try not to let your insecurity show.

options.text: Continue

new-york-week-two-decline.title: Taking Your Time
story: You suggest maybe the next one. 'I'm still settling in,' you say. 'I don't want to be overwhelmed yet. Is that okay?' You watch Alex's face carefully. Are they disappointed? Relieved? It's hard to tell.

'Of course,' Alex says. 'No pressure. There will be other events.' They seem genuine, but you notice they don't push back or try to convince you. Is that respect for your boundaries or disappointment in your lack of enthusiasm?

The second week passes quietly. Alex goes to the Friday drinks without you. Comes home around 9 PM, a little tipsy, with stories about colleagues you don't know. You listen and nod and laugh at the right moments. But there's a gap opening up. A world Alex is entering that you're choosing to stay outside of.
For now, that feels safer. But you wonder if safe is the same as smart.

options.text: Continue

new-york-settling-gym.title: Endorphins and Strangers
story: You join a gym in your neighborhood. It's expensive - everything in New York is expensive - but the first class is free. You show up to a 6 PM spin class, self-conscious and sweaty before you even start.

The instructor is aggressively positive. The music is too loud. Everyone else seems to know exactly what they're doing. But by the end, you're drenched in sweat and somehow feel lighter. Not happy, but less heavy.

You start going three times a week. You learn the other regulars' faces even though you never talk. There's the woman who always takes the bike by the window. The guy who mouth-breathes through the whole class. The instructor who yells 'YOU'VE GOT THIS' like she actually believes it.
It's not friendship, but it's routine. It's something that's yours. And right now, that's enough.

options.text: Continue

new-york-settling-networking.title: The Professional Smile
story: You find a young professionals networking event in your industry. It's at a bar in Midtown, full of people in business casual, clutching drinks and business cards like lifelines. Everyone is performing confidence. You join the performance.

You shake hands. You make small talk. You laugh at jokes that aren't funny. You exchange LinkedIn connections with people you'll never message. It's exhausting and artificial, but you leave with five new contacts and one coffee invitation for next week.

The coffee meeting is with Jenna, a project manager at a tech startup. She's been in New York for three years. 'The first six months are brutal,' she says. 'But it gets better. You find your people. You find your rhythm.' You want to believe her.
You keep going to events. You keep collecting contacts. You're building something, slowly. A professional identity separate from being Alex's partner. That has to count for something.

options.text: Continue

new-york-settling-hobby.title: Finding Joy
story: You join a cooking class in Chelsea. It's ridiculous and expensive and exactly what you need. Ten strangers making pasta from scratch while drinking wine and laughing when things go wrong. Nobody asks what you do for work. Nobody cares that you just moved here. You're just people making food together.

You meet Sarah, who moved here from Seattle two years ago. Marcus, who's lived in New York his whole life but is 'bad at making friends as an adult.' Kira, who's going through a divorce and taking cooking classes to avoid her empty apartment. Real people with real struggles.

After class, you all go to a bar. You talk about New York, about loneliness, about how hard it is to build a life from scratch. Someone suggests making it a regular thing - cooking class and drinks every other Wednesday.
You say yes. You have friends now. Maybe. Tentative friends. People who know your name and answer your texts. It's a start.

options.text: Continue

new-york-settling-alex-circle.title: Borrowed Social Life
story: You tell Alex you want to be more involved in their work world. 'Include me,' you say. 'I want to meet your people. Be part of your life here.' Alex lights up. 'Really? Yeah! There's a happy hour next week. And Sofia from marketing is having a dinner party...'

You become a fixture at Alex's work adjacent events. You learn everyone's names. Remember their kids' ages. Ask thoughtful follow-up questions. You become known as Alex's supportive partner. The person who always shows up, always smiles, always plays the role perfectly.
It's fine. Really. These people are nice. The conversations are pleasant. You're being social, getting out of the apartment, supporting Alex's career. All good things.

But you're also always 'Alex's partner' instead of just yourself. You have no stories that don't start with 'we.' You're building Alex's social life, not your own. And slowly, quietly, you're disappearing into their shadow.

options.text: Continue

new-york-month-one-pre.title: The Invitation
story: One month in, Alex's company throws a happy hour. 'You should come,' Alex says over breakfast. 'Meet the team. See my office. It'll be fun.'
There's something in their voice - eagerness mixed with... is that nervousness? You can't quite place it.

Your remote work has started. You're finding your rhythm with video calls and deadlines. The apartment feels less like a cage and more like a workspace. You have some semblance of a routine. But Alex's work world is still mostly a mystery to you.

Names without faces. Stories without context. Jordan, the colleague Alex keeps mentioning, is especially abstract. They're working on the Morrison account together. Alex talks about Jordan like they're brilliant and hilarious and just a bit intense. You're curious to finally meet this person.

options.text: You're excited to meet Alex's colleagues and see their office.
You're nervous but willing. First impressions matter.
You're skeptical. Work events are always awkward.

new-york-month-one-excited.title: Game Face On
story: You agree enthusiastically. This is what you've been waiting for - a chance to see Alex in their element, to understand this huge part of their life. You spend the day planning your outfit, practicing conversation starters, psyching yourself up.

When you arrive at the office that evening, you're determined to make a good impression. The office is everything Alex described and more. Floor-to-ceiling windows, modern furniture, a coffee bar that would make Starbucks jealous. You can see why Alex loves it here.

Alex introduces you around, clearly proud. Marcus from accounting. Sofia from marketing. Everyone is friendly, polished, confident. You match their energy, smiling and shaking hands and making the kind of small talk that greases the wheels of professional socializing.

options.text: Continue

new-york-month-one-nervous.title: Stepping Into Their World
story: You agree, but your stomach twists with anxiety. What if you say something wrong? What if Alex's colleagues don't like you? What if you're awkward and Alex regrets inviting you? But you put on your good outfit - the one that says 'I'm successful and definitely not feeling insecure' - and show up anyway.

The office is intimidating. Everything is glass and chrome and expensive. People move with purpose, even at a happy hour. Everyone seems to know exactly who they are and where they belong. You smile and try to project confidence you don't feel.

Alex introduces you around with obvious pride, which helps. Marcus from accounting. Sofia from marketing. Everyone is polite. You shake hands, make appropriate noises, try to remember names you'll probably forget.

options.text: Continue

new-york-month-one-skeptical.title: Professional Theater
story: You agree, but without much enthusiasm. Work events are always performative. Everyone pretending to be friends, pretending to care about each other's weekends, pretending the forced fun is actually fun. But Alex wants you there, so you'll go.

The office is exactly what you expected - aggressively trendy, trying too hard to be cool. Floor-to-ceiling windows that probably cost more than your apartment. A coffee bar with beans that have their own origin story. Corporate money pretending not to be corporate.

Alex introduces you around. You smile and nod and shake hands. Marcus from accounting seems nice enough. Sofia from marketing has kind eyes. You're going through the motions, waiting for the part where you can leave without being rude.

options.text: Continue

new-york-jordan-first-meeting.title: And Then There's Jordan
story: Then Alex says, 'Oh, and this is Jordan. We're working on the Morrison account together.'

Jordan is... exactly what you were afraid of. Charming smile, expensive suit, effortless charisma. The kind of person who makes everyone around them feel slightly less interesting. They shake your hand with perfect pressure - firm but not aggressive.

'I've heard so much about you,' Jordan says, making eye contact that lasts just a beat too long. 'Alex talks about you constantly.' But there's something in the way they look at Alex when they say it. Something that makes your stomach twist.

You notice things. Small things, probably meaningless things. The way Jordan touches Alex's arm when they laugh. The inside joke about the Morrison presentation that you're not part of. The way Alex's energy changes when Jordan walks over - more animated, more engaged.
This is Jordan. The name you've been hearing for weeks. And now they have a face, a presence, a reality. You're not sure how you feel about that reality.

options.text: Be warm and friendly to Jordan. Maybe your initial discomfort is just in your head.
Be polite but reserved. Keep professional distance.
Be subtly territorial. Make it clear Alex is spoken for.

new-york-jordan-meeting-friendly.title: Benefit of the Doubt
story: You decide to give Jordan a chance. Your insecurity is probably making you see threats where there aren't any. You smile genuinely, ask about their work on the Morrison account, express interest in their career path. Kill them with kindness.

Jordan responds well. They're actually pretty easy to talk to. Funny, self-deprecating, genuinely complimentary about Alex's work ethic. 'I'd be lost without them,' Jordan says. 'They're carrying half the project.' Alex blushes at the praise.

You spend twenty minutes talking to Jordan about New York, about the company, about adjusting to corporate culture. They're nice. Really nice. Maybe you were overthinking the arm touch, the energy shift. Maybe they're just Alex's colleague and nothing more.
By the time you and Alex leave, you feel silly about your initial reaction. Jordan is fine. This is fine. Everything is fine.

options.text: Continue

new-york-jordan-meeting-reserved.title: Polite Distance
story: You smile but don't commit. You answer Jordan's questions briefly. You don't ask follow-ups. You're polite - not rude, never rude - but you're not warm either. You're establishing boundaries without saying a word.

Jordan seems to notice the distance. They try a few times to engage you, then gracefully back off, turning their attention back to Alex and the project talk. You stand there, present but not participating, watching the way they interact.

Alex notices too. You catch them glancing at you with a slightly confused expression. Like they're trying to figure out why you're being so reserved. You'll probably have to explain later. Or maybe you won't.
By the time you leave, you haven't learned much about Jordan except that Alex clearly enjoys their company. And that feels like enough information for now.

options.text: Continue

new-york-jordan-meeting-territorial.title: Marking Territory
story: You slip your arm around Alex's waist. You make a point of mentioning 'our apartment,' 'our move,' 'our life together.' You laugh at Alex's jokes just a bit louder than necessary. You're subtle about it - you think you're subtle about it - but you're making your presence known.

Jordan gets the message. You can see it in the slight tightening around their eyes, the way they take a small step back, the way their hand doesn't land on Alex's arm again. Good. Let them know where things stand.

Alex doesn't seem to notice the undercurrent. They're oblivious, happily talking about work, introducing you to more people, showing off their office. But you notice. And Jordan notices. And now there's a line drawn in the sand, invisible but unmistakable.
On the walk home, Alex seems happy. 'Everyone loved you,' they say. You smile and squeeze their hand. Mission accomplished.

options.text: Continue

paris-apartment-choice.title: Finding Your Parisian Home
story: The real estate agent - who speaks rapid French and minimal English - shows you three apartments. Each one represents a different vision of your Paris life.
Option A: 11th arrondissement, fourth floor walkup. Tiny but charming, with shutters that open to rooftops and Sacré-Cœur in the distance. Close to Alex's office. €1,400/month.
Option B: Marais, third floor. More space, exposed beams, a real bathroom. Trendy neighborhood, great cafés, tourists everywhere. Alex would have a 25-minute metro ride. €1,700/month.

Option C: 20th arrondissement, ground floor. Actually affordable, quiet residential area, real Parisians instead of expats. But far from everything. Alex would commute 45 minutes each way. €1,100/month.

options.text: 11th arrondissement - Prioritize being close to Alex's work and seeing the city from your windows
Marais - Balance charm, space, and location in the heart of things
20th arrondissement - Prioritize authenticity and affordability over convenience

paris-apartment-11th.title: Rooftop Views
story: You choose the fourth floor walkup in the 11th. The stairs are brutal - you're wheezing by the third floor - but when you open those shutters and see the rooftops stretching toward Sacré-Cœur, it's worth it.

The apartment is tiny. Your bed takes up most of the bedroom. The kitchen is basically a corner. But the light! The light pours through those windows like liquid gold, and you understand why everyone romanticizes Paris.

Moving day is chaos in French. The movers refuse to carry furniture up four flights. You and Alex haul boxes until your legs shake. But that night, exhausted and surrounded by unpacked chaos, you open a bottle of cheap wine and look out at your new city.
'We're really in Paris,' Alex says, arm around your shoulders. 'We're really in Paris,' you echo. And for one perfect moment, everything feels possible.

options.text: Continue

paris-apartment-marais.title: Heart of the City
story: You pick the Marais apartment. It's more expensive, but you can actually have people over. The exposed beams give it character. The bathroom has a real shower, not just a handheld thing over a tub. This is a place you can build a life.

The neighborhood is perfect. Cafés on every corner. A bakery that makes bread so good you want to cry. Museums within walking distance. The only downside: tourists. So many tourists. But you'll learn to navigate around them.

Moving day is surprisingly manageable. The building has an elevator. The super speaks some English. By evening, most of your things are in place. You collapse on your new couch - an actual couch! - and Alex brings you wine from the shop downstairs.
'I think we're going to be happy here,' Alex says. Looking around your beautiful apartment in the heart of Paris, you think they might be right.

options.text: Continue

paris-apartment-20th.title: Real Paris
story: You go for the 20th arrondissement. It's not glamorous. It's not what people picture when they think 'Paris.' But it's real. Families. Immigrants. People who actually live here instead of visiting. And the price is right.

The apartment is ground floor, which means you hear every person walking by. But it also means no stairs. You have space. An actual bedroom separate from your living room. Storage. For Paris, this is luxury.
The commute worries you. Forty-five minutes on the Metro each way means Alex will lose an hour and a half per day. But they wave it off. 'I'll read,' they say. 'It's fine.' You hope they mean it.

Moving day is easy. Ground floor, helpful neighbors who speak no English but help anyway. That night, you sit in your quiet apartment and hear real life happening outside - conversations in Arabic and Portuguese and French, music from the apartment above, a child laughing. This is home now.

options.text: Continue

paris-first-morning.title: Premier Matin
story: Your first morning in Paris. Alex's alarm goes off at 7:00 AM. They fumble for their phone, squinting at the unfamiliar bedroom. The light through the windows is different here. Everything is different here.

You're already awake. You've been awake since 6:00, listening to the sounds of a Paris morning. Church bells. Street cleaners. Someone yelling in French. It's beautiful and terrifying in equal measure.

Alex moves quietly, getting ready for their first day. You can see the nerves in the way they check their outfit twice, practice pronouncing their boss's name, gather their things with trembling hands. This job, this city, this life - it's all about to become real.

options.text: Get up and make breakfast. Send them off with coffee and encouragement.
Pretend to sleep. Let them have this moment alone to gather themselves.
Get up but let them lead. Be present without being intrusive.

paris-breakfast-together.title: Café au Lait
story: You get up. 'I'm making coffee.' Alex's face floods with relief. You stumble through using the unfamiliar coffee maker, cursing in English when you can't figure out the buttons. Alex laughs, the tension breaking.

You sit together with terrible coffee - you definitely need to figure out this machine - and croissants from yesterday that are still somehow better than anything back home. 'I'm terrified,' Alex admits. 'My French is awful. What if I screw this up?'
'You're going to be amazing,' you say, taking their hand. 'And if you screw up, you'll do it in French, which makes it automatically more sophisticated.' Alex laughs, kisses you, heads out the door.
You watch from the window until they disappear around the corner. Then you turn back to your apartment in Paris and think: what now?

options.text: Continue

paris-pretend-sleep.title: Silent Support
story: You keep your eyes closed. Let Alex have this morning to themselves. You hear them moving around - the coffee maker, the closet, the bathroom. The sounds of someone trying to be quiet in an unfamiliar space.

Part of you wants to get up. To wish them luck. To be the supportive partner. But you're also overwhelmed. This city, this language, this massive change you've both committed to. You need a few more minutes of not having to be okay.

The door closes. Alex is gone. You open your eyes to morning light in a Paris apartment. You're alone in a city where you don't speak the language. Day one of what might be a beautiful adventure or a terrible mistake.
You lie there for another twenty minutes before forcing yourself up. The apartment feels bigger and lonelier without Alex in it.

options.text: Continue

paris-quiet-presence.title: Companionable Silence
story: You get up quietly. Start water boiling. Alex emerges from the bathroom, surprised but pleased to see you. You work in companionable silence - you making coffee, them getting dressed, both of you moving in the careful dance of people who love each other but don't need to fill every moment with words.

You hand them coffee. They accept with a grateful nod. You sit together on boxes that should be furniture, watching Paris wake up through your windows. 'Big day,' you finally say. 'Terrifying day,' Alex admits.
'You've got this.' 'We've got this,' Alex corrects, squeezing your hand. Then they're gone, and you're left with your coffee and a whole day in a brand new country.
You finish your coffee slowly, watching the street below. This is your life now. Time to figure out what that means.

options.text: Continue

paris-first-day-alone.title: Seule Paris
story: The apartment is quiet. You're surrounded by boxes and jetlag and the weight of what you've just done. You left your country, your language, your entire familiar world to follow Alex to Paris. It was romantic in theory. In practice, it's terrifying.
Your phone buzzes. Alex: 'Office is beautiful. Everyone speaks so fast! How's unpacking?' You look around at the disaster zone. You haven't unpacked anything. You've barely moved.
You have a month before your remote work starts. A month to learn enough French to survive. A month to prove to yourself - and maybe to Alex - that you belong here.

options.text: Unpack and nest. Make this place feel like home.
Get out and explore. You need to see your new city.
Find a cafe and people-watch. Ease into Paris slowly.

paris-unpack-nest.title: Creating Home
story: You attack the boxes like they're the enemy. Every item unpacked is a small victory. Books on shelves. Clothes in the armoire. Kitchen items in cabinets that smell like someone else's life. By afternoon, the apartment looks almost livable.

You take breaks to figure out how things work. The washing machine has settings you don't recognize. The stove is gas, not electric. The light switches are in unexpected places. Everything familiar is slightly wrong, and everything new is slightly intimidating.

But by the time Alex texts 'Leaving office! Be home soon!', you've made progress. The apartment has gone from chaos to merely messy. When Alex walks in, exhausted and overwhelmed, they stop in the doorway. 'You did all this?' You shrug. 'We needed a home, not a storage unit.'
That night you eat takeout on actual furniture. Small victories.

options.text: Continue

paris-explore-city.title: Into the Unknown
story: You leave the boxes for later. You need to meet Paris. You grab your phone, your wallet, and your courage. Time to get lost.

Everything is beautiful and frustrating in equal measure. The buildings, the bridges, the way the light hits the Seine. But also: you can't read the metro map. You don't know how to ask for directions. You accidentally order three coffees instead of one because your French is terrible.

You wander for hours. Notre-Dame. The Latin Quarter. You get lost six times and nearly cry twice. But you also feel alive. You're in Paris. Actually in Paris. Walking streets Hemingway walked, seeing sights artists painted. It's overwhelming and perfect.

When Alex comes home, the apartment is still full of boxes. But you have stories. About getting lost, about the kind woman who helped you, about the most perfect croissant you've ever eaten. Alex listens and laughs and suddenly the boxes don't matter as much.

options.text: Continue

paris-cafe-slow.title: The Art of Watching
story: You find a cafe two blocks from your apartment. Nothing fancy - just tables on the sidewalk and coffee that costs half what it would in New York. You order in broken French. The waiter smiles kindly, responds in English. You feel like a tourist. You are a tourist.

You sit for three hours. Watching. Parisian women in scarves that somehow look elegant instead of trying too hard. Old men reading newspapers. Students arguing passionately about something you can't understand. The rhythm of a city that doesn't care if you figure it out or not.
You realize: you could sit here every day. Learn the patterns. Become a regular. Let Paris reveal itself slowly instead of trying to conquer it all at once. There's no rush. You have time.
When Alex comes home, you're calm. Centered. The boxes can wait. Paris isn't going anywhere, and neither are you.

options.text: Continue

paris-first-week.title: La Première Semaine
story: The first week establishes a rhythm. Alex leaves at 8:00 AM for the office near Republique. You wake up alone in a city that doesn't speak your language. Alex comes home at 7:00 PM with stories about colleagues, projects, the amazing coffee machine at work.

You're drowning. The French on signs might as well be hieroglyphics. The metro system is a mystery. You went to the grocery store and nearly cried because you couldn't figure out which milk was which. Being incompetent as an adult is humbling and horrible.

But there are small victories. You found a bakery where the owner now recognizes you. You learned how to say 'encore du pain, s'il vous plaeet.' You figured out the washing machine. Tiny steps that feel enormous.

Friday night, Alex comes home with news. 'Riley wants to grab drinks next Friday. Show us around, since they've been here three years. You'll love them - they're originally from the States too.' There's excitement in Alex's voice. And something else. Nervousness?

options.text: Agree enthusiastically. You need someone who can help you navigate Paris.
Agree but feel cautious. You remember Riley had feelings for Alex once.
Suggest maybe just Alex goes. You're not ready for socializing yet.

paris-week-two-eager.title: Looking for Connection
story: You jump at the chance. Riley has been here three years. They know the good restaurants, the hidden gems, how to navigate French bureaucracy. You need that knowledge. You need an ally who speaks English and understands what it's like to be foreign.

The second week passes in preparation. You practice French phrases. You Google Riley online (their Instagram is impressive - stylish photos at trendy locations). You tell yourself this is networking. You're building a Paris support system. The fact that Riley once had feelings for Alex is history. Ancient history.
By Friday, you're actually excited. Alex seems pleased that you're pleased. 'Riley's great,' they promise. 'You're going to get along so well.' You hope they're right.

options.text: Continue

paris-week-two-cautious.title: Guarded Hope
story: You agree, but you remember what Alex told you. Riley had feelings for Alex in college. Feelings that might have been mutual if timing had been different. That was years ago, sure. But feelings don't always respect timelines.

The second week passes slowly. You prepare mentally - telling yourself not to be jealous, not to be insecure, not to see threats where there aren't any. Riley is Alex's friend and colleague. You can handle this like an adult.

But you also pay attention. You notice how often Riley's name comes up. 'Riley showed me this great cafe.' 'Riley says Parisians are cold until they're warm.' 'Riley thinks my French pronunciation is getting better.' Riley, Riley, Riley.
By Friday, you're nervous. But you smile and act excited because that's what partners do.

options.text: Continue

paris-week-two-decline.title: Boundaries
story: You suggest Alex goes without you. 'I'm still adjusting,' you say. 'I don't think I'm ready for socializing in French yet. Is that okay?' You watch Alex's face. Disappointment? Relief?

'Of course,' Alex says. 'No pressure. Riley will understand.' But you notice they don't argue. Don't try to convince you. Is that respecting your boundaries or being relieved they can see Riley alone?

The second week passes. You're alone more. Alex goes to Friday drinks. Comes home around 10 PM, speaking rapid French-accented English about Riley showing them a secret bookshop, a perfect wine bar, a shortcut through the Marais.

You listen and smile and try not to calculate how many hours Alex spent with Riley today. Try not to wonder what you're missing by staying home. Try not to feel like you're already losing a competition you didn't know you were in.

options.text: Continue

new-york-weekend-one.title: Saturday Morning
story: It's your first Saturday in New York. Alex wakes up early, energized. 'Want to explore today? We could hit a museum, walk the Brooklyn Bridge, find that brunch place everyone raves about.'

You're exhausted. The week of unpacking, adjusting, trying to figure out your new life has caught up with you. Part of you wants to go, to be the fun adventurous partner. Part of you wants to stay in bed and pretend none of this is real.
You also have work emails piling up. Your remote job starts Monday, and you're not prepared. And the apartment is still half-unpacked. Adulthood is just endless choices between things you should do.

options.text: Go explore with Alex. Quality time is more important than productivity right now.
Suggest a low-key day. Maybe just a walk and then rest.
Tell Alex you need to work. They can explore without you.

new-york-weekend-adventure.title: Adventurers
story: You push through exhaustion. 'Let's do it all,' you say. Alex grins, and you spend the day being tourists in your new city. The Met. The Brooklyn Bridge. Overpriced brunch where you wait forty-five minutes for a table.

It's exhausting and perfect. You take selfies with the Manhattan skyline. You get lost in Central Park. You feel like the couple you were when you first fell in love - adventurous, spontaneous, choosing each other over everything else.

By the time you get home, your feet hurt and you're broke and you haven't dealt with your work emails. But Alex says 'Best day ever' and kisses you, and you think maybe priorities are about what you choose, not what you sacrifice.

options.text: Continue

new-york-weekend-lowkey.title: Gentle Saturday
story: 'Let's take it easy,' you suggest. 'Just a walk? I need to decompress.' Alex looks slightly disappointed but nods. 'Whatever you need.'

You walk through your neighborhood. No plan, no destination. Find a coffee shop. Sit in a park. Talk about everything and nothing. It's not Instagram-worthy, but it's real. Alex tells you about work stress. You admit you're more overwhelmed than you've been letting on.
'We're in this together,' Alex reminds you. 'We don't have to conquer New York in a week.' You squeeze their hand. Some days, just existing in the same space as someone you love is enough.

options.text: Continue

new-york-weekend-solo.title: Separate Saturdays
story: 'I really need to prep for Monday,' you say. 'You should go explore. I'll be boring anyway.' Alex's face falls slightly. 'You sure?' You nod, already feeling guilty.

Alex leaves around 10 AM. You work for two hours, then spend three hours scrolling social media and feeling sorry for yourself. You could have gone. You should have gone. But you also needed space, needed time alone to process everything.

Alex comes home at 5 PM with stories and photos. You smile and listen and don't mention that you spent most of the day doing nothing. A gap is forming. Small, barely noticeable. But gaps have a way of growing if you're not careful.

options.text: Continue

new-york-monday-work-starts.title: Work From Home
story: Monday. Your remote work officially begins. Alex leaves for the office at 7 AM. You roll out of bed at 8:45, make coffee, and sit at your makeshift desk (a folding table from Target). Welcome to working from home in a city where you have no friends.

The video calls are fine. Your coworkers are nice. The work is familiar. But between meetings, you're alone. So alone. The apartment is quiet except for sirens and car horns outside. You eat lunch at your desk. You don't talk to another human being in person all day.

At 6 PM, you close your laptop. You've been productive. You've done your job. But you're also desperate for Alex to come home so you can hear another voice, see another face, remember that you're not totally alone in this city.
Alex texts at 6:15: 'Jordan and I are stuck on this presentation. Gonna be another hour. Order dinner without me?' Your heart sinks.

options.text: Text back supportively. You understand work emergencies.
Text back that you're disappointed but try to hide it.
Call them. You need to hear their voice, explain you had a hard day.

new-york-supportive-response.title: Understanding Partner
story: You text: 'No problem! Good luck with the presentation. I'll save you some dinner.' You mean it. Work is work. Alex is building something important.

But alone in the apartment, eating takeout by yourself, you feel the loneliness like a physical weight. This is your life now. Waiting for Alex to have time for you. Being understanding while feeling invisible.

Alex comes home at 8:30, apologetic and exhausted. You smile and warm up dinner and listen to stories about the presentation. You're being the perfect partner. But inside, you're keeping score. And that never ends well.

options.text: Continue

new-york-hidden-disappointment.title: Swallowed Words
story: You text: 'Ok. See you when you get home.' Brief. Neutral. With just enough edge that Alex might notice you're upset. Or might not. You watch the three dots appear and disappear. Appear and disappear. Finally: 'Thanks for understanding ❤️'

Do you understand? You're not sure. You eat dinner alone, again. You try to read but can't focus. You're angry and guilty about being angry and lonely and frustrated that you can't just say 'I need you to come home.'

Alex arrives at 8:30. 'Sorry about that.' You shrug. 'It's fine.' It's not fine. But saying so feels needy, feels like you're being the demanding partner. So you swallow the words and let them poison you from the inside.

options.text: Continue

new-york-call-explain.title: Honest Moment
story: You call. Alex answers, surprised. 'Hey, what's up?' You hear office noise in the background. 'I had a rough first day,' you admit. 'I know you're busy, I just... I needed to hear your voice.'

Silence. Then: 'I'm so sorry. I didn't even think to check in. How was it really?' You talk for five minutes. About the loneliness. About missing human contact. About needing them. It's vulnerable and scary.

'I'm wrapping up right now,' Alex says. 'I'll be home in twenty minutes. We'll order good food and you can tell me everything. Jordan can finish this without me.' You hear Alex closing their laptop. They're choosing you.

They come home. You talk. Really talk. About adjusting, about loneliness, about needing to check in with each other more. It's not easy, but it's honest. And honesty is how you survive hard transitions together.

options.text: Continue

new-york-week-three.title: Three Weeks In
story: Three weeks. You're finding a rhythm, even if it's not always comfortable. Work, dinner, sleep, repeat. Alex's name for Jordan comes up constantly. 'Jordan suggested...' 'Jordan thinks...' 'Jordan and I are...' You try not to keep count. You keep count anyway.

Wednesday evening, Alex comes home excited. 'Jordan invited us to their place for dinner this weekend. They want to get to know you better. Are you free Saturday?' There's hope in Alex's voice. They want you to like Jordan. They want their worlds to blend.

You think about the happy hour where you met Jordan. The charm, the charisma, the easy connection with Alex. You think about how much Jordan's name has invaded your home. You have to decide how to navigate this.

options.text: Accept enthusiastically. Time to give Jordan a real chance.
Accept reluctantly. You'll go but you're not excited about it.
Decline politely. You're not ready to socialize with Jordan yet.

paris-weekend-one.title: Premier Weekend
story: Your first Saturday in Paris. Alex wakes up energized. 'Let's explore! The Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, maybe a boat ride on the Seine?' They're speaking in that excited voice that makes you want to say yes to everything.

But you're exhausted. And overwhelmed. And secretly terrified about trying to navigate a day in a city where you can't speak the language. What if you need to order food? What if you get lost? What if everyone realizes you're a fraud who doesn't belong here?
Also, you should probably unpack more. And maybe study French. And definitely figure out how to set up your work computer before Monday.

options.text: Push through anxiety. This is Paris! You're going to explore together.
Suggest staying in the neighborhood. Baby steps into your new city.
Tell Alex to go without you. You need more time to adjust.

paris-weekend-adventure.title: Tourist Life
story: 'Let's do it all,' you say, ignoring the knot in your stomach. You spend the day being tourists. The Louvre is overwhelming - too much art, too many people, your feet hurt after an hour. But the Mona Lisa is smaller than you expected and somehow that's perfect.

You take selfies in front of the Eiffel Tower. You eat crepes from a street vendor. Alex orders for you in their stilted French, and you feel both grateful and infantilized. But you're doing it. You're being in Paris together.

On the Metro ride home, exhausted and overstimulated, Alex leans against your shoulder. 'Today was perfect.' You're not sure perfect is the word you'd use - more like 'survived' - but you smile. You're trying. That counts for something.

options.text: Continue

paris-weekend-neighborhood.title: Local Living
story: 'Let's explore our neighborhood first,' you suggest. 'I want to know where we actually live before we tourist all over the city.' Alex looks slightly disappointed but agrees.

You walk the streets near your apartment. Find the best boulangerie (after trying three different ones). Discover a park with old men playing petanque. Sit at a cafe for two hours because nobody rushes you. This is the Paris the guidebooks don't capture.
You're still overwhelmed by the language, but the barista at the corner cafe now recognizes you. That feels like victory. Small, unglamorous victory. But victory nonetheless.

options.text: Continue

paris-weekend-alone.title: Solitary Saturday
story: 'I think I need a day to myself,' you admit. 'To process everything. Is that okay?' Alex's face falls, but they nod. 'Of course. Take all the time you need.'

Alex leaves. You spend the day unpacking, studying French on Duolingo, and feeling guilty. Should you have gone? Are you being a bad partner? Are you wasting your precious time in Paris by hiding in your apartment?

But you also feel better. Sometimes being in a relationship means knowing when you need to be alone. When Alex comes home with stories and photos, you listen and don't mention that you spent six hours earning imaginary internet points on a language app.

options.text: Continue

paris-monday-work.title: Remote in Paris
story: Monday. Your remote work begins. Alex leaves at 8 AM, navigating their commute and their new French colleagues. You sit at your makeshift desk in Paris and join video calls with people who have no idea you're on a different continent.

'How's the weather there?' your boss asks. You glance at your Paris window. Rain streaking the glass, gray Parisian skies. 'Fine,' you say, not mentioning you're 6,000 miles from the office. Time zones are brutal - your 9 AM meeting is their 3 PM. Your day starts and ends later than Alex's.

Between meetings, you're alone. In a foreign country. Unable to just run errands or meet a friend for lunch. The isolation is profound. You eat lunch alone while trying to watch French TV to improve your comprehension. You understand maybe one word in ten.
Alex texts at 6:30 PM: 'Riley wants to grab drinks after work. Show me around the neighborhood. Okay if I'm home around 9?' Your stomach twists.

options.text: Respond supportively. Alex should bond with colleagues.
Ask them to come home. You've had a hard first day.
Say it's fine but feel resentful inside.

paris-supportive-response.title: Generous Partner
story: You text: 'Of course! Have fun. Riley knows all the best places.' You mean it. Alex needs to build connections. You want them to be happy.

But sitting alone in your Paris apartment, eating dinner by yourself, hearing French conversations through the walls that you can't understand, the loneliness is crushing. This is your life now. Waiting. Being understanding. Disappearing.

Alex comes home at 10 PM, slightly tipsy, with stories about a hidden wine bar Riley showed them. You smile and listen. You're being the perfect partner. But you're also building a wall of resentment, one supportive text at a time.

options.text: Continue

paris-ask-come-home.title: Voice Your Needs
story: You call. 'Hey, I know you're building connections, but I really had a rough day. Any chance you could come home instead? We could order in, you could tell me about work...' You trail off, feeling needy.

Pause. Then: 'Of course. I'll tell Riley another time. Are you okay?' Relief floods you. 'I will be. I just need you.' Twenty minutes later, Alex walks through the door with takeout from the Thai place down the street.

You talk about your day. About the isolation. About how much harder this is than you expected. Alex listens, really listens. 'We need to check in more,' they say. 'I can't forget that you're adjusting to a whole new country.'
It's not a magic fix. But it's communication. And that's how you survive transitions - by actually talking about them instead of suffering in silence.

options.text: Continue

paris-resentful-agreement.title: Poisoned Silence
story: You text: 'Sure.' One word. You watch the three dots appear, disappear. Appear again. Finally: 'Thanks! Love you!' You don't respond.

You eat dinner alone, scrolling through photos of your friends back home doing normal things in a language they understand. You're resentful and guilty about being resentful. Why can't you just be happy for Alex? Why does their success feel like your failure?

Alex comes home at 10:15. 'Sorry, lost track of time.' You shrug. 'It's fine.' It's not fine. But saying so feels like admitting you're not cut out for this. So you say nothing, and the gap between you grows.

options.text: Continue

paris-week-three.title: Trois Semaines
story: Three weeks in Paris. Your French is slightly less terrible. You can order coffee without panic-sweating. You've learned which metro lines actually run on time. Small victories in a city that doesn't care if you figure it out.

Riley's name comes up constantly. 'Riley says the best markets are on weekends.' 'Riley showed me this shortcut through the Marais.' 'Riley thinks I should try the regional director position.' Riley, Riley, Riley. You try not to picture them - charming, French-fluent, with years of history with Alex.

Thursday evening, Alex comes home excited. 'Riley invited us to their place Saturday. Dinner party with some other colleagues. You'll finally meet their partner Sam too. Want to go?' There's hope in Alex's voice. They want you to like their people.

options.text: Accept eagerly. You need to meet Riley properly and build your own Paris social life.
Accept but feel anxious. Meeting Riley feels like a test you didn't study for.
Decline. You're not ready to socialize in French while meeting your partner's work crush.

new-york-dinner-accept.title: Open Mind
story: 'That sounds great!' you say with genuine enthusiasm. 'I'd love to get to know Jordan better.' Alex beams. You're being the partner they need - open, social, willing to embrace their new life.

Saturday comes. Jordan's apartment in Murray Hill is gorgeous - high ceilings, minimalist decor, the kind of place that screams 'I have my life together.' Jordan greets you with wine and warmth. 'I'm so glad you could come.'

The evening is... fine. Jordan is charming, funny, a good host. You eat expensive cheese and drink good wine and laugh at the right moments. But you also notice things. The way Jordan touches Alex's arm. The inside jokes. The easy intimacy of people who spend 40 hours a week together.
On the way home, Alex squeezes your hand. 'Thank you for tonight. I know Jordan can be a lot, but they're important to me.' You nod. You're trying. You're really trying.

options.text: Continue

new-york-dinner-reluctant.title: Going Through the Motions
story: 'Sure, we can go,' you say with forced enthusiasm. Alex doesn't seem to notice the lack of genuine excitement. Or maybe they're choosing not to notice.

Saturday. Jordan's apartment is exactly what you expected - impressive, expensive, designed to impress. You smile and make small talk and eat food you can't pronounce. You're playing the role of Supportive Partner at Jordan's Dinner Party.

But your guard is up the whole time. You notice every touch, every look, every laugh between Jordan and Alex. You're cataloging evidence for a case you haven't filed yet. By the time you leave, you're exhausted from performing normalcy.

Alex seems oblivious. 'That was fun, right?' You nod. What else can you say? 'I spent three hours analyzing every interaction between you and your coworker for signs of emotional infidelity'? That sounds insane. Maybe you're being insane.

options.text: Continue

new-york-dinner-decline.title: Drawing Lines
story: 'I think I'll pass,' you say carefully. 'I'm not really feeling up to socializing this weekend.' Alex's face falls. 'Really? Jordan specifically asked me to invite you...' The guilt is immediate.
But you hold firm. 'You should still go. I just need a quiet weekend.' Alex nods, but something shifts in their expression. Disappointment? Relief? You can't quite read it.

Saturday night, you sit alone in your apartment while Alex is at Jordan's. You tell yourself you made the right choice, that you're setting healthy boundaries, that you don't have to like all of Alex's coworkers. But you also feel like you're failing a test you didn't know you signed up for.
Alex comes home at midnight with stories you weren't part of. The gap widens.

options.text: Continue

paris-dinner-accept.title: Into Riley's World
story: 'Yes, absolutely!' you say. 'I've been wanting to meet Riley properly.' And you mean it. You need to stop seeing Riley as a threat and start seeing them as a person.

Saturday arrives. Riley's apartment in the Marais is stunning - high ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows, art on the walls that probably costs more than your rent. Riley greets you with la bise, those cheek kisses that still feel foreign. 'Welcome! So glad you could come.'

The evening is actually lovely. Riley is charming, yes, but also kind. Their partner Sam is a graphic designer, warm and funny. Other colleagues are there - interesting people with interesting stories. You drink wine, eat incredible food, practice your terrible French.

But you also notice. The way Riley and Alex slip into inside jokes. The way they touch each other's arms. The easy intimacy of people with history. Sam notices you noticing. Gives you a sympathetic smile. Maybe you're not paranoid after all.

options.text: Continue

paris-dinner-anxious.title: Test Performance
story: 'Okay,' you say, your stomach already knotting. 'I'll come.' Alex doesn't notice your hesitation, or chooses not to.

Saturday. You spend two hours getting ready, changing outfits three times. Riley's apartment is in the Marais - of course it is. Perfectly decorated, perfectly located, perfectly Riley. You walk in already feeling like you don't measure up.

You smile. You make conversation in broken French and perfect English. You meet Sam, who seems nice but also close to Riley in that way that makes you wonder if they notice the way Riley looks at Alex. You eat cheese you can't pronounce and pretend you're having fun.
But really, you're performing. Performing confidence. Performing like you belong. Performing like you're not threatened. By the time you leave, you're exhausted and Alex is oblivious.

options.text: Continue

paris-dinner-decline.title: Boundary Line
story: 'I don't think I'm ready for that yet,' you admit. 'My French isn't good enough. I'll just embarrass myself and you.' Alex's face falls. 'Riley specifically wanted to meet you...'

You hold firm. 'You go. Build your connections. I'll be fine.' Alex looks disappointed but doesn't push. They go alone Saturday evening. You sit in your apartment, eating takeout, wondering if you're being smart or self-destructive.

Alex comes home at midnight. Tells you about the dinner, about Riley's amazing apartment, about Sam who you would have liked. Every detail is a reminder of what you missed. Of the gap that's growing between Alex's Paris life and yours.
You made a choice. You just hope it was the right one.

options.text: Continue

new-york-phone-moment.title: The Phone
story: It's 11 PM on a Tuesday. Alex is in the shower. Their phone buzzes on the nightstand. Once. Twice. Three times. You glance over. Text notifications from Jordan.
You've never snooped before. You trust Alex. You've always trusted Alex. But the phone is right there. Alex's passcode is your anniversary. It would take five seconds to look.
Three more buzzes. Jordan is really texting a lot for 11 PM on a work night.

options.text: Don't look. Trust is more important than curiosity.
Just glance at the lock screen. That's not really snooping.
Open the phone. You need to know.

new-york-phone-dont-look.title: Choosing Trust
story: You look away deliberately. Whatever Jordan is texting about is between them and Alex. You're not going to be that partner. You're not going to start snooping.

Alex comes out of the bathroom, picks up their phone, scrolls briefly. 'Jordan is freaking out about the Morrison presentation tomorrow. So dramatic.' They laugh, put the phone down, climb into bed next to you.

'Everything okay with you two?' you ask carefully. Alex looks confused. 'With me and Jordan? Yeah, why?' You shrug. 'Just checking in.' Alex kisses your forehead. 'You're the only one I need to be okay with.'
You chose trust. It feels vulnerable and scary and right.

options.text: Continue

new-york-phone-lock-screen.title: Just a Glance
story: You lean over. Just to see the lock screen. That's not really invading privacy, right? The messages preview:
'I need your advice' 'Can I call you?' 'I know it's late but' 'You're the only one who gets it' 'Thanks for today btw'
Your heart sinks. Nothing explicitly inappropriate. But 'you're the only one who gets it'? At 11 PM? You're the only one who should be the only one.
Alex comes out, sees you looking at the phone. 'What's up?' You try to act casual. 'Jordan's texting a lot.' 'Oh yeah, they're stressed about tomorrow. I'll call them back in a sec.'
In a sec. They're going to call Jordan back at 11 PM while you're right here. You swallow the protest. You glanced. That was your choice. Now you have to live with what you saw.

options.text: Continue

new-york-phone-open.title: Crossing the Line
story: You open the phone. Your hands are shaking. You know this is wrong but you do it anyway. You open the messages with Jordan.

It's... work stuff. Mostly. Presentation notes. Stressed venting about their boss. But then: 'I don't know what I'd do without you' and 'You make work actually bearable' and 'Dinner tomorrow? Just us?'
Just us? Your stomach drops. Then you hear the shower turn off. You close the phone, put it back exactly where it was. Your heart is pounding.

Alex comes out. Picks up their phone. Sees the notification. 'Jordan's melting down. Give me five minutes?' They step out of the bedroom to call. You sit there, guilt and suspicion warring in your chest.
You snooped. You violated trust. And you found... what? Evidence? Or just work friendship? You don't even know anymore.

options.text: Continue

new-york-month-two.title: Two Months In
story: Two months in New York. You've settled into a routine. You know your local spots. Your remote work is going well. You've made a few acquaintance-friends, if not deep connections. Alex is thriving at work - they just got a big project and a raise.

Everything looks perfect from the outside. But you feel the distance growing. Jordan's name is everywhere. 'Jordan and I are working late.' 'Jordan recommended this restaurant.' 'Jordan thinks I should apply for director.'

It's Thursday night. Alex just told you they have a work dinner tomorrow. With Jordan. Just the two of them. 'It's a networking thing,' Alex explains. 'We're meeting a potential client. Super boring, you'd hate it.'
Maybe that's true. Or maybe you're being deliberately excluded. You can't tell anymore.

options.text: Ask if you can come. Even if it's boring, you want to be included.
Ask questions. Where? What time? When will you be home?
Say fine and don't push. You don't want to seem controlling.

new-york-ask-to-join.title: Invitation Request
story: 'Can I come?' The words come out before you can stop them. Alex looks surprised. 'To a work dinner? It's going to be three hours of business talk...'
'I don't mind. I want to support you. And I've been wanting to try more networking myself.' You're reaching. You both know it.
Alex hesitates. 'Let me check with Jordan if it's okay to bring a plus-one.' They text. You watch the three dots. Jordan responds: 'Client might find it weird if it's not just us two. Rain check?'
Alex looks apologetic. 'Sorry. Next time?' You nod. But you just asked to come to a work dinner and got told no. That's a new low.

options.text: Continue

new-york-ask-questions.title: Due Diligence
story: 'Where's the dinner?' you ask, trying to sound casual. Alex names a restaurant you've never heard of. 'What time?' 'Probably 7 to 10?' 'And Jordan's going?' 'Yeah, we're meeting the client together.'

You're gathering information like you're building a case. Alex notices. 'Are you okay with this?' They look genuinely concerned. You have a choice: say what you're really feeling or pretend everything's fine.
'I'm fine,' you lie. 'Just curious.' Alex relaxes. They don't see that you've just committed to a night of anxiety and worst-case scenarios while they're out with Jordan.

options.text: Continue

new-york-say-fine.title: Swallowed Feelings
story: 'That's fine,' you say breezily. 'Have fun.' Alex looks relieved. 'Thanks for being understanding. I'll try not to be too late.'

But you're not understanding. You're seething. A work dinner. Just Alex and Jordan. On a Friday night. Three hours minimum. You imagine them at a restaurant, laughing over wine, Jordan touching Alex's arm, neither of them thinking about you sitting alone at home.
You don't say any of this. You smile. You're fine. Everything's fine. The resentment crystallizes into something hard and cold in your chest.

options.text: Continue

new-york-friday-alone.title: Friday Night
story: Friday. Alex leaves at 6:30 for the dinner. 'I'll text you updates!' they promise. You watch them walk out the door, dressed up, excited, not thinking about how you're spending your Friday night alone. Again.

You try to distract yourself. Start a show. Order takeout. Text friends back home. But mostly you're thinking about Alex and Jordan at a restaurant. Are they talking about work? Or are they talking about life, dreams, the things partners talk about?

At 9:30, you haven't heard from Alex since their text at 7: 'Client is late. Might be longer than expected.' You check Find My Friends. They're still at the restaurant. You check Instagram. Nothing. You check... everything. You're spiraling.
At 10:45, Alex finally texts: 'So sorry! Dinner ran long. Heading home now.' It's been four and a half hours. Who has a work dinner for four and a half hours?

options.text: Confront them when they get home. This is unacceptable.
Act normal. See if they bring up how late it was.
Pretend to be asleep. You can't deal with this right now.

new-york-confront-late.title: The Fight
story: Alex comes home at 11:15. You're waiting up. 'Four and a half hours?' you say before they can even close the door. 'For a work dinner?'
Alex looks taken aback. 'The client was chatty. We couldn't just leave.' 'You couldn't text more than once in four hours?' Your voice is rising. You can hear it but can't stop it.
'I thought you were fine with this! You said you were fine!' 'I'm not fine! I spent Friday night alone while you were out with Jordan until almost midnight!'
The fight escalates. Things are said. You accuse. Alex defends. Lines are drawn. When you finally go to bed, it's in angry silence. You've crossed a threshold. You can't uncross it.

options.text: Continue

new-york-act-normal.title: Performance Mode
story: Alex comes home at 11:15. You're on the couch, pretending to watch TV. 'Hey! Sorry that ran so long. The client was so chatty.' They kiss your forehead like nothing's wrong.

'How was it?' you ask, voice neutral. 'Boring,' Alex says. 'Three hours of sports talk and business jargon. You would have hated it.' They're telling you that you're better off, but you hear that you weren't missed.

You make small talk. Ask about the client. Laugh at Alex's stories. Play the role of Understanding Partner. But inside, you're keeping score. Four and a half hours. One text. This is strike two, or three, or you've lost count.
You're a pressure cooker. Eventually, you're going to explode.

options.text: Continue

new-york-pretend-asleep.title: Avoidance
story: You hear Alex come in at 11:15. You're in bed, eyes closed, breathing slow and steady. Pretending. Alex tiptoes around, trying not to wake you. Gets ready for bed quietly. Slides in next to you carefully.

You lie there, back to them, rigid with resentment and pretend sleep. They don't know you're furious. They think you're fine. You're letting them think you're fine while building a case against them in your head.
This is how relationships die. Not with explosions, but with thousands of unsaid things festering in the dark.

options.text: Continue

new-york-morning-after-fight.title: Cold Morning
story: Saturday morning. You wake up with fight-hangover - that heavy feeling of knowing you said things you can't unsay. Alex is already awake, making coffee in silence. The air between you is thick.
'We should talk about last night,' Alex says carefully. You have a choice. Double down on your anger, apologize and reconcile, or continue the silent treatment.

options.text: Apologize. You overreacted and you know it.
Stand your ground. You have legitimate concerns.

new-york-apologize-fight.title: Olive Branch
story: 'I'm sorry,' you say. 'I shouldn't have attacked you the second you walked in. That wasn't fair.' Alex's shoulders relax. 'I'm sorry too. I should have communicated better. I got caught up and forgot you were home waiting.'

You talk. Really talk. About loneliness, about feeling secondary, about needing more communication. It's not perfect, but it's honest. Alex promises to be better about checking in. You promise to voice concerns before they become explosions.
The fight wasn't fun, but the aftermath brings you closer. Sometimes you have to break a little to rebuild stronger.

options.text: Continue

new-york-stand-ground.title: Holding the Line
story: 'I wasn't wrong,' you say. 'Four hours is excessive. One text in four hours is disrespectful. And doing it with Jordan specifically...' You trail off.
'This is about Jordan,' Alex says flatly. 'You don't trust me.' 'I trust you. I don't trust the situation.' 'There is no situation! Jordan is my coworker!'

The fight reignites. No one apologizes. No one backs down. Eventually Alex leaves - 'I need space' - and you're alone again, wondering if you just pushed your partner away or if they were already gone.

options.text: Continue

new-york-morning-after-fine.title: Normal Facade
story: Saturday morning. You wake up and continue pretending everything's fine. Alex makes breakfast. You eat together. You talk about weekend plans. Everything is surface-level perfect and underneath completely wrong.
You're not fighting. But you're also not okay. The resentment is there, just buried. Waiting.

options.text: Continue

new-york-morning-after-avoid.title: Continued Silence
story: Saturday morning. Alex doesn't know anything's wrong. You continue the pretense. You're friendly but distant. Fine but not fine. Alex doesn't push. Maybe they don't notice. Maybe they're choosing not to notice.
The gap grows wider.

options.text: Continue

paris-phone-moment.title: Le Téléphone
story: It's 10 PM on a Wednesday. Alex is in the shower. Their phone buzzes on the nightstand. Multiple times. You glance over - texts from Riley. In French. Which you can't read well enough.

You've never been that partner. The one who checks phones. But Riley's texts are constant. And they're in French, which feels like a secret language you're locked out of. The phone is right there. The passcode is your anniversary.
More buzzes. Riley is really texting a lot for 10 PM.

options.text: Don't look. Maintain trust even when it's hard.
Glance at notifications. Just to see if you can understand.
Open the phone and translate. You need to know.

paris-phone-trust.title: Choosing Faith
story: You deliberately look away. Whatever Riley and Alex are discussing is their business. You're not going to snoop. You're going to trust.
Alex emerges, checks their phone. 'Riley's freaking out about something their ex said. So much drama.' They roll their eyes affectionately, put the phone down, climb into bed. 'How was your day?'
You talk. About your day, your struggles with French, your loneliness. Alex listens. You chose trust, and right now, it feels like the right choice.

options.text: Continue

paris-phone-glance.title: Surface Check
story: You lean over to see the lock screen. The texts are in French but you catch words: 'besoin' (need), 'comprends' (understand), 'seul' (alone), 'merci' (thank you). You can't get the full context but the emotional tone is... intimate?

Alex comes out. Sees you looking. 'Riley being dramatic again. Their ex is causing issues.' You nod. You saw the texts but couldn't understand them. Which is worse - not looking or looking and still not knowing?

options.text: Continue

paris-phone-translate.title: Breaking Trust
story: You open the phone. Screenshot the messages. Use Google Translate. Your hands are shaking. The translation is rough but the gist is clear: Riley saying they need someone who understands them, thanking Alex for always being there, saying they don't know what they'd do without Alex.
Nothing explicitly romantic. But emotionally intimate in a way that makes your chest tight. The shower turns off. You close everything, put the phone back. Your heart hammers.
Alex comes out, checks messages, responds briefly. 'Riley drama. Their ex is back being messy.' They don't know you just violated their privacy. You sit with that guilt and that knowledge.

options.text: Continue

paris-month-two.title: Deux Mois
story: Two months in Paris. You can order in restaurants without panic. You can navigate the Metro. You've found a favorite cafe. From the outside, you're adapting. From the inside, you're drowning.

Riley is everywhere in Alex's stories. The commute together. The shared jokes. The 'you had to be there' moments. Alex is building a life in Paris, and you're not sure how much of that life includes you versus tolerates you.
Thursday evening. Alex announces they have a work event Friday night. Team drinks, then possibly dinner. With Riley. Obviously with Riley. 'I might be late,' Alex says. 'Don't wait up.'

options.text: Ask to come along. You need to be part of their world.
Say fine but ask for a time estimate and updates.
Say nothing. You're tired of feeling needy.

paris-ask-come-drinks.title: Inclusion Request
story: 'Can I come?' you ask. Alex looks surprised. 'It's a work thing... everyone will be speaking French...' 'I can handle it. I want to be there.'
Alex hesitates. 'Let me see if spouses are invited.' They check with Riley. The answer: 'It's employees only tonight. Sorry!' You're shut out. Again.

options.text: Continue

paris-ask-time.title: Reasonable Questions
story: 'What time should I expect you?' you ask. 'Drinks at 7, so probably home by midnight?' That's five hours. You nod. 'Can you text me updates?' 'Of course,' Alex promises.
Friday comes. You get one text at 8 PM: 'At dinner now.' Then silence until 12:45 AM when Alex stumbles in, apologetic and tipsy. You were reasonable. They weren't.

options.text: Continue

paris-say-nothing.title: Silent Suffering Begins
