story: You say nothing. Alex leaves Friday evening. You sit alone in your Paris apartment, unable to even comfort-watch TV because everything is in French. You check your phone compulsively. No updates.
Alex comes home at 1 AM. You pretend to be asleep. The resentment crystallizes into something cold and hard.

options.text: Continue

new-york-photo-arrives.title: Unknown Number
story: Friday evening. Alex texts: 'Emergency presentation prep. Gonna be another late one. Don't wait up.' You're staring at your phone when it buzzes again.
But this time it's not from Alex. It's an unknown number. A photo. Your stomach drops before your brain even processes what you're seeing.

The image shows Alex and Jordan at a dimly lit bar. Jordan's hand is on Alex's arm. Both of them are laughing. The angle is deliberate - intimate, suspicious. The message reads: 'Thought you should know what Friday night presentations look like. - A Friend'
Your hands are shaking. Your heart is hammering. This is the moment everything changes. How you react right now will determine everything that comes next.

options.text: Call Alex immediately. Demand an explanation right now.
Text Alex the photo. Let them see you know.
Sit with it. Process before reacting.
Show up at that bar. See for yourself what's really happening.

new-york-photo-call-immediately.title: The Phone Call
story: You call. It rings four times. Five. You're about to hang up when Alex answers, breathless. 'Hey, what's up? I'm in the middle of'
'Where are you?' Your voice is tight. 'I told you, presentation prep with' 'Are you at a bar with Jordan?' Silence. Long, terrible silence.
'Someone sent me a photo,' you say. 'You and Jordan. At a bar. Jordan touching your arm. Both of you looking very cozy for a work emergency.'
More silence. Then: 'Can we talk about this when I get home? This isn't I can't do this over the phone.' That's not a denial. That's not 'you're crazy.' That's 'I can't do this over the phone.'

options.text: Demand they come home right now.
Hang up and go to the bar yourself.
Agree to wait but you're furious.

new-york-photo-text-it.title: Digital Evidence
story: You screenshot the photo. Send it to Alex with no message. Just the image. Let them interpret. Let them explain. Let them panic.

Three dots appear immediately. Disappear. Appear. Disappear. Your heart is pounding. Finally, a message: 'Where did you get this??' Not 'this isn't what it looks like.' Not 'I can explain.' Just 'where did you get this.'
You type: 'Anonymous number. Is this what presentation prep looks like?' Send. Three dots. Disappear. Your phone rings. Alex calling.

options.text: Answer. Hear what they have to say.
Ignore the call. Let them squirm.
Answer but say you're coming to the bar.

new-york-photo-process.title: The Pause
story: You sit with the photo. Really look at it. They're at a bar. Jordan's hand is on Alex's arm - but is Alex pulling away? Leaning in? You can't tell from a still image. They're laughing - about what? Work? Something else?
Someone sent this to hurt you. To make you doubt. To create drama. But is the photo real? Is the context real? Or is someone manipulating you into destroying your own relationship?
You have evidence of... what exactly? Your partner having a drink with a coworker? Or your partner having an affair? The photo doesn't tell you which. Your response will determine what happens next.
You take a breath. Then another. You're not going to make a decision from a place of panic. You're going to be smart about this.

options.text: Wait for Alex to come home. Have a calm conversation like adults.
Go to the bar but observe first before confronting.
Call a friend for advice before doing anything.

new-york-photo-demand-home.title: The Ultimatum
story: 'Come home. Right now.' Your voice is ice. 'I need to finish' 'I don't care what you need to finish. Come. Home. Now.'
Alex sighs. You hear muffled conversation - probably telling Jordan they have to leave. 'I'll be there in twenty minutes.' They hang up.
You pace the apartment. Twenty minutes feels like hours. You're playing scenarios in your head. Best case: innocent work meeting, bad angle. Worst case: everything you feared is true.
When Alex walks in, they look guilty. Or defensive. Or scared. You can't tell anymore.

options.text: Show them the photo silently. Let them explain first.
Immediately ask: Are you cheating on me?
Start with: Who sent me this and why?

new-york-photo-wait-furious.title: Controlled Fury
story: 'Fine. Finish your work meeting.' The sarcasm is heavy. 'We'll talk when you get home. If you get home.' You hang up before Alex can respond.
You pace. You make tea you don't drink. You look at the photo fifty more times. You imagine confrontations. You imagine lies. You imagine your life falling apart.
Two hours later, Alex comes home. They look nervous. Good. They should be nervous.

options.text: Meet them at the door with the photo.
Sit on the couch. Make them come to you.

new-york-photo-answer-call.title: The Explanation Begins
story: You answer. 'I can explain,' Alex says immediately. The worst words. If you have to say you can explain, you probably can't.

'I'm listening.' Your voice is flat. 'We ARE working. Jordan and I are at the bar because the office closed and we needed somewhere to keep going. That photo is taken out of context. Someone is trying to mess with us.'
'Jordan's hand is on your arm.' 'They were pointing at something on my laptop. It's not there's nothing happening here. Please believe me.'
Do you believe them? Can you?

options.text: Ask them to come home immediately to talk in person.
Tell them you're coming to the bar to see for yourself.
Say you need time to think. Hang up.

new-york-photo-ignore-call.title: Silence as Weapon
story: You silence the call. Let it go to voicemail. Immediately, a text: 'Please pick up. I can explain. It's not what it looks like.'
Another text: 'Someone is trying to cause problems. Please don't let them.'
Another: 'I'm coming home. We need to talk about this face to face.'
Twenty minutes later, Alex bursts through the door, panicked and apologetic. You're waiting.

options.text: Let them talk first. See what they say unprompted.
Immediately confront: Explain that photo. Now.

new-york-photo-observe.title: Detective Mode
story: You grab your coat. You're going to the bar, but you're not going to storm in. You're going to observe. See what's really happening before you make accusations you can't take back.

The bar is ten minutes away. You can see them through the window before you go in. They're sitting at a corner table. Laptops open. Papers spread out. Jordan's hand had been on Alex's arm in the photo, but now they're both typing.

It looks like work. It actually looks like work. But the bar is dim, intimate. They're sitting close. Jordan laughs at something, leans toward Alex. Alex smiles back in a way that makes your chest tight.
You could go in. Or you could keep watching. Or you could go home and pretend you never saw any of this.

options.text: Go in. Confront them now that you've seen more context.
Keep watching. Gather more information.
Leave. You've seen enough. Wait for Alex at home.

new-york-photo-call-friend.title: Outside Perspective
story: You call your best friend from back home. They answer on the second ring. 'Hey! What's up!' 'I need advice.' Your voice cracks. 'Tell me everything,' they say.
You explain. The photo. The anonymous message. Jordan's constant presence in your life. Your friend listens. Then: 'What does your gut say?'
'My gut says something's wrong. But my gut also says I might be paranoid.' 'Those aren't mutually exclusive,' your friend points out. 'You can be paranoid AND something can be wrong.'
'What would you do?' you ask. 'I'd need more information,' they say. 'One photo from an anonymous sender isn't enough. But it's enough to ask questions.'

options.text: Take their advice. Wait for Alex and ask calm questions.
Ignore their advice. Go to the bar. You need to see for yourself.
Ask them to stay on the phone with you while you figure this out.

paris-riley-lyon-announced.title: Le Week-end Lyon
story: Four months into your Paris life, Alex comes home with news. 'My company is doing a retreat in Lyon this weekend. Team building, strategy sessions, the usual corporate stuff.' They're folding laundry, not quite meeting your eyes. 'It's employees only, so...'
'So I can't come,' you finish. Alex nods, apologetic. 'I wish you could. It would be more fun with you there.'

You know Riley will be there. Riley, who works directly with Alex. Riley, whose name peppers every conversation. Riley, who had feelings for Alex once upon a time. And now they're spending a weekend together in Lyon while you sit alone in Paris.
That night, you're helping Alex pack when their phone buzzes. You glance over. Riley's text: 'Can't wait for our weekend away! Just like old times '

options.text: Ask Alex directly about that text. What does 'old times' mean?
Say nothing about the text but express general discomfort about the trip.
Pretend you didn't see it. You don't want to seem controlling.
Make a joke about it to test Alex's reaction.

paris-lyon-ask-about-text.title: Direct Question
story: 'What did Riley mean by just like old times?' you ask, trying to keep your voice neutral. Alex glances at their phone. 'Oh. We used to do weekend trips in college. Road trips, hiking, that kind of thing. Riley's just being nostalgic.'
'Nostalgic about time you spent together before me.' It comes out more bitter than you intended. Alex stops packing. 'Are you uncomfortable with this trip?'
Here's your chance. You can be honest about your fears. Or you can backpedal and pretend everything's fine.

options.text: Be honest. Yes, you're uncomfortable with them spending a weekend with someone who used to have feelings for them.
Backpedal. Say you're fine, just making conversation.
Turn it around. Ask if Riley still has feelings for them.

paris-lyon-express-discomfort.title: Vague Concerns
story: 'I'm not super comfortable with this trip,' you admit. 'A whole weekend with your team. With Riley.' You don't mention the text. You're testing to see if Alex addresses it on their own.
Alex sits down next to you. 'What specifically makes you uncomfortable?' They seem genuinely curious, not defensive. This is your chance to either be specific about Riley or keep it vague.

options.text: Be specific about Riley. Their history, the constant presence, your insecurity.
Stay vague. Just say you'll miss them and weekends apart are hard.

paris-lyon-pretend-unseen.title: Swallowed Words
story: You say nothing about the text. You smile. You help Alex pack. You play the role of Supportive Partner Who Isn't Threatened. But inside, 'just like old times' echoes like a warning bell.

Friday morning arrives. Alex leaves for Lyon. You kiss them goodbye. 'Have fun,' you say. You don't say 'don't do anything I wouldn't approve of' or 'remember you have a partner' or any of the thousand anxious thoughts racing through your head.
The door closes. You're alone in Paris for the weekend. And Alex is in Lyon with Riley. Just like old times.

options.text: Continue

paris-lyon-joke-about-it.title: Humor as Defense
story: 'Just like old times?' you say with forced lightness. 'Should I be worried?' You're joking. Except you're not joking. You're testing.
Alex laughs. 'Riley's being dramatic. It's a work retreat, not a college reunion.' They don't seem to register your actual concern beneath the joke. Or they're choosing not to.
'Right. Of course.' You smile. The moment passes. But you didn't get the reassurance you needed. You got dismissed.

options.text: Push a little more. Make it clear you're actually concerned.
Let it go. You tried to bring it up and got shut down.

paris-lyon-backpedal.title: False Reassurance
story: 'No, I'm fine,' you lie. 'Just making conversation.' Alex looks relieved. 'Good. Because it's really just a boring work thing. You'd hate it anyway - hours of presentations in French.'

They're giving you an out. Telling you that you're better off without this experience. But you hear: you're not part of this part of my life. Friday comes. Alex leaves. You're alone with your thoughts and your fears.

options.text: Continue

paris-lyon-stay-vague.title: Missed Opportunity
story: 'I'll just miss you,' you say. It's true but it's not the whole truth. 'It's weird being apart on weekends.' Alex softens. 'I'll miss you too. I'll text you constantly. Promise.'

They mean it. But they didn't address Riley. Because you didn't give them the chance. You stayed safe instead of honest. Friday arrives. Alex leaves with promises to text. You wait to see if they keep those promises.

options.text: Continue

paris-lyon-ask-feelings.title: The Real Question
story: 'Does Riley still have feelings for you?' The question hangs in the air. Alex looks genuinely surprised. 'What? No. That was years ago. We're friends and colleagues. That's it.'
'You're sure?' 'I'm sure.' Alex takes your hand. 'You're the one I chose. You're the one I moved to Paris with. Riley is in the past.'
You want to believe them. But believing them means trusting them for a whole weekend in Lyon. Can you do that?

options.text: Choose to trust. Set clear boundaries but let them go.
Say you trust them but internally you don't. Silent suffering begins.

new-york-show-photo-silent.title: Silent Accusation
story: You hold up your phone. Show Alex the photo. Say nothing. Let the image speak for itself. Alex's face goes through a journey - confusion, recognition, then something that might be panic or might be anger.
'Where did you get this?' Not 'this isn't what it looks like.' Not 'I can explain.' Just 'where did you get this.' Like the source matters more than the content.
'Anonymous number,' you say. Your voice is surprisingly steady. 'Someone thought I should know what Friday night presentations look like.'

Alex sinks onto the couch. 'This is... someone is trying to mess with us. This is exactly what it looks like - work. Jordan and I were at the bar because we needed somewhere to finish the Morrison presentation. That's Jordan pointing at my laptop screen, not... whatever this is trying to imply.'

options.text: Believe them. Ask who would send this and why.
Question them. Why a bar? Why so late? Why didn't you text more?
Don't believe them. This looks intimate regardless of the excuse.

new-york-ask-cheating.title: The Direct Question
story: 'Are you cheating on me?' The words come out raw. Alex's eyes widen. 'What? No! God, no. Why would you' They stop. See your phone. The photo. Understanding dawns.
'Where did that come from?' 'Anonymous number. Someone sent it to me while you were at your work emergency.' You can't keep the sarcasm out of the word 'work.'
Alex sits down heavily. 'I'm not cheating on you. That's Jordan and me working. Someone took a photo at the worst possible moment and sent it to you to cause exactly this reaction. And it's working.'

options.text: You want to believe them but you need more information.
The photo speaks for itself. Explain the hand on your arm.
Who would do this? Focus on the anonymous sender.

new-york-ask-who-sent.title: The Mystery
story: 'Who would send this to me?' you ask. 'Who has both our numbers and a reason to want us to fight?' Alex thinks. You can see them processing. 'Someone at work. Someone who doesn't want Jordan and me to succeed on this project. Or...' they trail off.

'Or what?' 'Or someone who's interested in one of us. Someone who wants to create problems.' You hadn't thought of that. This could be about breaking you up so Alex is available. Or so Jordan is available.

'Do you believe that?' you ask. 'Do you really think someone is trying to manipulate us?' 'I think this photo is real but the context is wrong,' Alex says carefully. 'And I think someone knew exactly what buttons to push to make you doubt me.'

options.text: Choose to trust Alex. Focus on finding who sent it.
This feels like deflection. Address the photo first, mystery second.
Maybe you're being manipulated. Or maybe Alex is gaslighting you.

new-york-believe-investigate.title: Partnership Mode
story: 'Okay,' you say. 'I believe you. But someone sent this for a reason. Who would want to mess with us?' You've shifted from accusation to investigation. Alex's shoulders drop with relief.

'Someone at work,' Alex says immediately. 'Jordan and I are both up for the same promotion. If we're distracted by personal drama, we're less competitive.' 'So this is corporate sabotage?' 'Maybe. Or someone's interested in one of us and wants to clear the field.'
You sit next to Alex. Look at the photo together. 'We need to figure this out,' you say. 'Together.' Alex takes your hand. 'Thank you for believing me. I know how this looks.'
You chose trust. It's scary and vulnerable and it might be the thing that saves you.

options.text: Continue

new-york-question-details.title: Interrogation
story: 'Why a bar?' you ask. 'Why not the office? Why not a coffee shop?' 'The office closes at 9. Coffee shops close early. The bar was close and open late.' It makes sense. You hate that it makes sense.
'Why didn't you text me more than once?' 'I was working. I thought you'd be fine. I didn't think—' 'You didn't think I'd be sitting at home, alone, wondering where you were and who you were with?'

Alex winces. 'You're right. I should have communicated better. But I wasn't doing anything wrong. I was literally typing on my laptop the entire time. Ask Jordan.' 'I don't want to ask Jordan. I want you to not put me in situations where I have to wonder.'

options.text: Demand better communication going forward.
You're still not satisfied. Something feels off.

new-york-dont-believe.title: Trust Broken
story: 'This looks intimate,' you say. 'Work or not, you're sitting close, they're touching you, you're both clearly comfortable in a way that makes me uncomfortable.' Your voice is rising. You can't stop it.
'We were looking at a laptop screen!' 'At a bar! At midnight! While I was home alone!' The fight escalates. Neither of you is listening. You're both just defending, attacking, circling.

Alex stands. 'I can't do this. I can't defend myself against a photo taken out of context by someone trying to sabotage us. Either you trust me or you don't.' 'Right now, I don't,' you say. The words hang there, sharp and final.
Alex grabs their jacket. 'I need space. I'll stay at Jordan's' 'Of course you will!' 'because Jordan has a couch and I can't be here right now.' The door slams.

options.text: Let them go. You need space too.
Follow them. Don't let them leave angry.

new-york-need-more-info.title: Clarification
story: 'I want to believe you,' you say. 'But I need to understand. Walk me through the evening. Every detail.' Alex nods. Takes a breath. Starts explaining.

The office closed at 9. They needed somewhere to work. Jordan suggested the bar - it's quiet on weeknights, has good wifi. They ordered coffee, not alcohol. They worked for three hours straight. The photo must have been taken around 10:30 when Jordan was pointing at something on the screen.

'Who would photograph you?' 'Someone from the office who was there. Marcus maybe - he's competing for the same promotion. Or...' Alex hesitates. 'Or someone interested in me or Jordan who wants to cause problems.'
The story hangs together. But does that mean it's true? Or just well-constructed?

options.text: The story makes sense. Choose to trust.
Ask to see their phone. Verify the timeline.
You want to believe but you can't. Not yet.

new-york-explain-touch.title: The Detail
story: 'Explain Jordan's hand on your arm.' You're looking at the photo again. That touch. It looks... familiar. Comfortable. Too comfortable.

Alex takes the phone. Studies the image. 'They were pointing at the screen. This is mid-gesture. If you had the photo from one second later, you'd see them pulling back. This is one frame of an innocent moment made to look like something else.'
'It doesn't look innocent.' 'Because whoever took this photo framed it that way. That's the point. They knew exactly what angle would make you doubt me.'
You're so tired. Tired of doubting. Tired of defending your doubts. Tired of this conversation. 'I don't know what to believe,' you admit.

options.text: Choose to believe Alex's explanation.
You need time apart to think clearly.
Suggest couples counseling. You can't navigate this alone.

new-york-who-sent.title: Detective Work
story: 'Let's figure out who sent this,' you say. 'That feels more productive than fighting.' Alex looks surprised. 'Really?' 'If someone's trying to sabotage us, I want to know who.'

You both sit. Look at the photo forensically instead of emotionally. The angle suggests someone sitting nearby. The bar looks familiar - Alex has mentioned it before. 'This is the bar near your office,' you say. 'Yeah. We go there sometimes after work.'

'Who else was there tonight?' Alex thinks. 'I didn't see anyone from work. But someone could have been there without me noticing.' You check the phone number. It's not in your contacts. You try calling back. Goes straight to a disconnected message. Burner phone.
'Someone went through effort,' you observe. 'This wasn't casual. This was planned.'

options.text: Report it to Alex's HR. This is workplace harassment.
Focus on your relationship. Don't let whoever sent this win.

new-york-deflection-call.title: Staying Focused
story: 'This feels like you're deflecting,' you say. 'Someone sent a photo of something real. You were at a bar with Jordan at midnight. That happened. Let's talk about that before we talk about conspiracy theories.'

Alex's face hardens. 'It's not a conspiracy theory. Someone literally sent you that photo to manipulate you.' 'And maybe they're manipulating you into thinking that's the issue instead of the actual issue - you prioritizing Jordan and work over me.'
The fight spirals. You're both angry now. Both feeling unheard. Both convinced you're right.

options.text: Take a break. Cool down before this gets worse.
Keep pushing. You need resolution tonight.

new-york-gaslighting-doubt.title: Spiral
story: 'How do I know you're not gaslighting me?' The question comes out before you can stop it. 'Making me think I'm crazy for being upset about something legitimately upsetting?'
Alex looks hurt. 'I'm not gaslighting you. I'm telling you the truth. Someone took a real moment and made it look like something it wasn't.' 'Or you're lying and making me feel bad for catching you.'
'If you really think that,' Alex says quietly, 'then we have bigger problems than this photo.' They're right. You know they're right. But you can't stop the spiral.

options.text: Apologize. You're letting fear make you mean.
Double down. Your feelings are valid even if you're expressing them badly.

new-york-trust-investigate.title: Us vs The Problem
story: You make a choice. You choose to trust Alex and treat this like you're on the same team against whoever sent the photo. 'Okay. We figure out who did this. Together.' Alex's whole body relaxes.

'Thank you,' they say. 'I know that's hard. I know how the photo looks.' 'It does look bad,' you admit. 'But looking bad and being bad aren't the same thing. And I trust you more than I trust some anonymous person with a camera.'

You spend the next hour analyzing. Who has both your numbers? Who benefits from you two fighting? Who was at that bar? By 2 AM, you have a theory: Marcus from accounting, who's competing with Alex and Jordan for the same promotion.
It's not proof. But it's a theory. And more importantly, you've spent two hours working together instead of tearing each other apart.

options.text: Report it to HR first thing Monday.
Confront Marcus directly.
Let it go. Focus on strengthening your relationship instead.

new-york-trust-story.title: Leap of Faith
story: 'Okay,' you say. 'I believe you.' Alex exhales like they've been holding their breath. 'Really?' 'Really. The story makes sense. And more importantly, you've never lied to me before. I'm not going to let an anonymous photo change that.'

Alex pulls you into a hug. 'We should figure out who sent this. This is harassment.' 'Later,' you say. 'Right now, I just need to be with you. Actually with you. Not fighting or investigating. Just... us.'
You order pizza at 1 AM. Talk about everything except the photo. Remember why you're together. By the time you fall asleep at 3 AM, the crisis feels smaller. Not gone, but manageable.

options.text: Continue

new-york-choose-believe.title: Active Trust
story: 'I choose to believe you,' you say deliberately. Those words: I choose. This isn't blind faith. This is an active decision to trust despite fear. Alex hears the difference.

'That means everything,' they say. 'I know this is scary. I know how the photo looks. But I'm choosing you too. Every day. This project with Jordan ends in two weeks. Then I'm requesting to work with a different team.'

'You'd do that?' 'I'd do anything to make you feel secure. You're more important than any work project. Any promotion. Anything.' The words matter. But the action - volunteering to change teams - matters more.

options.text: Accept the offer. You need that separation.
Don't require it. You trust them to handle Jordan professionally.

new-york-verify-phone.title: Trust But Verify
story: 'Can I see your phone?' you ask. 'I want to see the texts with Jordan tonight. See the timeline.' It's invasive. You know it's invasive. But you need it.
Alex hesitates. Not guilt-hesitation. Privacy-hesitation. Then hands over the phone. 'Password is our anniversary.' You unlock it. Open the messages with Jordan.

It's... exactly what Alex said. Work stuff. 'Meet at Hannigan's at 8?' 'Need to finish Morrison tonight.' 'Can you bring the updated numbers?' Nothing romantic. Nothing suspicious. Just two coworkers coordinating.
You hand back the phone. 'Thank you,' Alex says. 'For trusting me enough to verify instead of just assuming the worst.'

options.text: Apologize for doubting. You feel better now.
You verified one thing but you're still uneasy about Jordan.

new-york-suggest-counseling.title: Asking for Help
story: 'I think we need counseling,' you say. 'I don't know how to navigate this. The photo, the jealousy, the trust issues. I can't do this alone.' You expect Alex to resist. To say counseling is for people with real problems.
Instead: 'Okay. Yeah. Let's do that.' Relief floods you. 'Really?' 'Really. I don't want to lose you over a misunderstanding. If a therapist can help us communicate better, I'm in.'
It's 1 AM on a Friday night and you're making an agreement to go to couples therapy. It's not romantic. But it might be the most loving thing you've done for each other.

options.text: Research therapists together right now.
Just agree to do it and deal with logistics later. You need sleep.

new-york-take-break.title: Tactical Retreat
story: 'We need to stop,' you say. 'We're both tired. We're both reactive. We're not going to solve this at 1 AM.' Alex nods reluctantly. 'Okay. But we talk tomorrow? Actually talk?'

'Yes. Tomorrow. When we're both calm.' You go to bed angry. It's not what relationship advice says to do. But sometimes going to bed angry is better than fighting until you say something unforgivable.
In the morning, with coffee and daylight, everything feels less catastrophic.

options.text: Have a calm morning conversation.
The anger from last night hasn't faded.

new-york-push-resolution.title: Tonight
story: 'No. We're talking about this tonight. I'm not going to bed with this hanging over us.' Alex sighs. 'Fine. What do you want from me?'
'I want honesty. Real honesty. Are you attracted to Jordan?' The question lands like a bomb. Alex's eyes widen. 'What?' 'Answer the question.'

'Jordan is objectively attractive. But I'm not attracted TO them. There's a difference.' 'Is there?' 'Yes. I find lots of people attractive. I'm only attracted to you. I only want you. There's a difference and you know it.'
Do you know it? Or are you splitting hairs?

options.text: Accept the distinction. You do know the difference.
That's not good enough. The line is too blurry.

new-york-apologize-mean.title: Self-Awareness
story: 'I'm sorry,' you say. 'I'm scared and I'm lashing out. That's not fair to you.' Alex softens. 'I'm scared too. Scared of losing you over something I didn't do.'
'We're both scared,' you realize. 'And fear makes us mean to each other.' 'So what do we do?' Alex asks.
'We choose not to be mean. Even when we're scared. Especially when we're scared.'

options.text: Agree to communicate better going forward.
Suggest therapy to help navigate fear and communication.

new-york-double-down.title: Standing Ground
story: 'My feelings are valid even if I'm expressing them badly,' you insist. 'I'm not crazy for being upset.' 'I never said you were crazy,' Alex says carefully. 'I said someone is manipulating you.'
'Same thing!' 'It's really not.' The fight continues. You're both dug in. Both convinced you're right. Both bleeding but refusing to stop swinging.
By 3 AM, you're exhausted. No closer to resolution. Just more hurt.

options.text: Suggest sleeping separately tonight. You need space.
One more attempt at reconciliation before giving up.

new-york-demand-boundaries.title: Setting Terms
story: 'I need boundaries,' you say. 'Clear ones. No more late nights with Jordan without checking in every hour. No more work bars - if the office is closed, you come home. I need to feel prioritized.'

Alex nods. 'That's fair. I should have been better about communication. I will be better.' 'And I need you to tell Jordan about these boundaries. I need them to know I'm not comfortable with the current arrangement.'
Alex hesitates. 'That might make things awkward at work...' 'I don't care about awkward. I care about us.'

options.text: Insist. Jordan needs to know these boundaries exist.
Compromise. Alex sets boundaries without explicitly mentioning you.

new-york-still-suspicious.title: Lingering Doubt
story: 'I hear what you're saying,' you say. 'But I can't shake the feeling that something's off. Not cheating, maybe. But emotional intimacy that crosses lines.'
Alex looks frustrated. 'What would make you feel better? What do you need?' That's the question, isn't it? What would actually help?

options.text: Ask Alex to set boundaries with Jordan at work.
Suggest couples therapy to work through trust issues.
Admit you don't know. You're just... uncomfortable.

paris-riley-weekend-check.title: The Lyon Weekend
story: Saturday morning. Alex left for Lyon yesterday. You're alone in Paris, unable to even comfort-watch TV because everything's in French. You check your phone obsessively. The promised texts haven't come.
Finally, at 2 PM: 'Sorry! Meetings ran long. Miss you!' One text in 19 hours. You stare at it, trying to interpret tone through punctuation. Is 'Miss you!' genuine or guilty?

Another text, 20 minutes later: 'Riley says hi!' Riley says hi. Why? Did Riley see Alex texting you and wanted to be included? Or is Alex trying to make Riley seem harmless by mentioning them casually?

options.text: Respond normally. Ask about the retreat.
Respond but ask for more frequent updates.
Don't respond. See how long it takes them to follow up.
Call them. You need to hear their voice.

paris-respond-normal.title: Playing It Cool
story: You text back: 'How's it going? What are the meetings about?' Professional interest. Supportive partner. Definitely not sitting alone in Paris feeling abandoned.

Alex responds quickly this time. A paragraph about team building exercises and strategy sessions. It sounds boring. It sounds exactly like what they said it would be. You feel silly for being anxious.
Another text: 'Back to sessions. Talk tonight?' At least they're planning to talk tonight. That's something.

options.text: Continue

paris-ask-more-updates.title: Voicing Needs
story: You text: 'Miss you too! Can you check in more often? It's hard being here alone.' Vulnerable but honest. You hit send before you can overthink it.
Three dots appear. Disappear. Appear again. Finally: 'Of course. Sorry. Getting caught up in work mode. Will text more. Promise.' You want to believe the promise.
An hour later, another text: 'Coffee break. Thinking of you.' Then another hour later: 'Boring presentation about Q4 goals.' They're trying. That counts for something.

options.text: Continue

paris-dont-respond.title: Silent Test
story: You don't respond. You want to see how long it takes for a follow-up. Testing. You know you're testing. You do it anyway.
Three hours pass. You're checking your phone every five minutes. Nothing. Four hours. Five. At 7 PM, your phone rings. Alex calling.

'Hey, did you get my texts?' They sound worried, not guilty. 'Yeah.' 'Are you mad? You didn't respond and I got worried.' You're silent testing them and they're worried about you. Maybe you're the problem here.

options.text: Admit you were testing them. Be honest about insecurity.
Lie. Say you were busy and forgot to respond.

paris-call-check-in.title: Voice Connection
story: You call. Alex answers after three rings. 'Hey! Everything okay?' You can hear people in the background. They're in a social setting.
'Yeah, fine. Just wanted to hear your voice.' 'Hold on.' Shuffling sounds. The background noise fades. 'Okay, stepped outside. What's up?'

'Nothing's up. I just... I miss you.' 'I miss you too. This retreat is honestly pretty boring. Lots of corporate team building nonsense. Riley keeps making jokes about the facilitator which at least makes it bearable.'

options.text: Ask how much time they're spending with Riley specifically.
Just enjoy hearing their voice. Don't make it about Riley.

paris-saturday-night.title: Saturday Evening
story: Saturday night. 8 PM in Paris. You've been alone all day. You tried to go to a café but your French failed you and you ended up ordering the wrong thing and feeling humiliated. You came home and haven't left since.
Your phone buzzes. Not Alex. Unknown number. Your stomach drops. No. Not here too.

You open it. It's a photo. Alex and Riley at dinner. Wine glasses on the table. They're both laughing. Riley's hand is reaching toward Alex across the table. The message: 'Thought you should know how the work retreat is going. - A Friend'
The same pattern. Different city. Same fear.

options.text: Call Alex immediately. Demand explanation.
Send the photo to Alex. No words. Just the image.
Process first. This could be the same manipulation as NY.
Book a train to Lyon. See for yourself.

new-york-career-opportunity.title: Your Turn
story: Wednesday afternoon, middle of month two. You're on a video call with your boss. 'We want to promote you to senior position,' they say. 'But there's a catch - we need you in the office. Full time. Starting next month.'

Your stomach drops. You're in New York. Your company is back home. 'You want me to move back?' 'Or we open a New York office. You'd be the first employee there, building it from scratch. But that means long hours. Lots of travel back to headquarters. It's a big ask.'

It's your dream job. The position you've been working toward for three years. But it means competing with Alex's job for priority. It means late nights and stress and possibly the same problems you're giving Alex grief about.
You tell your boss you need 24 hours to think about it. Now you need to tell Alex.

options.text: Tell Alex immediately. This is a partnership decision.
Think it through alone first. Know what YOU want before discussing.
Decline the promotion. Alex's career is already stressful enough.
Accept immediately. This is YOUR career. You don't need permission.

new-york-tell-alex-promotion.title: Partnership Decision
story: That evening, you tell Alex about the offer. They listen carefully. When you're done, they ask: 'What do you want to do?' Not 'what should we do.' What do YOU want.

'I don't know,' you admit. 'It's my dream job. But the timing is terrible. You're dealing with work stress, the Jordan situation, and now I'd be adding my own chaos to the mix.' 'That shouldn't matter,' Alex says. 'This is your career. Your opportunity.'

'But it does matter. We're a team.' 'We are. Which means I support whatever you decide. If you want this promotion, we figure out how to make it work. If you don't, that's valid too. But don't not take it because of me.'
They're giving you permission. But is that what you need?

options.text: Accept the promotion. You both can have demanding careers.
Decline it. One high-stress job per relationship is enough.
Negotiate. Ask for the promotion but with flexible hours.

new-york-think-alone-promotion.title: Solo Processing
story: You don't tell Alex yet. You need to know what you want before you can discuss what's best for 'us.' You spend the evening walking through Central Park, weighing options.
Pro: Dream job. Money. Career advancement. Your own identity in New York beyond 'Alex's partner.' Con: Stress. Long hours. Becoming exactly what you've been criticizing Alex for. Hypocrisy.
By the time you get home, you've made a decision. Now you just need to tell Alex.

options.text: You've decided to accept. Tell Alex.
You've decided to decline. Tell Alex.
You still can't decide. Ask Alex for input.

new-york-decline-promotion.title: Sacrifice
story: You email your boss: 'Thank you for the opportunity, but I need to decline. The timing isn't right for my personal life.' Send. Done. You've made the decision unilaterally.

You don't tell Alex about the offer. Why make them feel guilty about something you've already decided? But the decision sits heavy. You gave up your dream job. For the relationship. Will Alex ever know? Should they?

options.text: Tell Alex anyway. They should know what you sacrificed.
Never mention it. This was your choice. No guilt required.

new-york-accept-promotion-solo.title: Independent Choice
story: You email your boss: 'I accept. Let's build the New York office.' You make the decision alone. It's YOUR career. You don't need Alex's permission to advance it.

That evening, you tell Alex. Frame it as done deal, not discussion. 'I got promoted. I'll be opening our New York office. Starts next month.' Alex looks surprised. 'Wow. Congratulations. That's... when did this happen?'
'Today. I needed to decide fast.' 'Without talking to me?' There's hurt in their voice. 'It's my job,' you say defensively. 'Right,' Alex says. 'Your job. Got it.'

options.text: Recognize you handled this badly. Apologize.
Stand your ground. You don't need permission for your own career.

new-york-mom-sick.title: The Call From Home
story: Thursday morning, month three. Your phone rings. It's your dad. He never calls. 'Your mom's in the hospital,' he says without preamble. 'They found something on her mammogram. We're waiting for biopsy results.'
The floor drops out from under you. 'What? When? Why didn't you call sooner?' 'It just happened yesterday. We didn't want to worry you until we knew more. But... I thought you should know.'
You hang up. Stare at your phone. Your mom might have cancer. You're in New York. She's a six-hour flight away. Alex is at work. You're completely alone with this news.

options.text: Book a flight home immediately. You need to be there.
Wait for biopsy results. No point flying if it's nothing serious.
Call Alex. You need support right now.
Call a friend from home. You need someone who knows your mom.

new-york-fly-home-mom.title: Emergency Flight
story: You book the next available flight. Leaves in four hours. You text Alex: 'Mom's in hospital. Flying home. Call me.' You throw clothes in a bag. Call your boss. 'Family emergency. I need a week.'
At the airport, Alex calls. 'What happened? Are you okay?' You explain while boarding. 'I'll come with you,' Alex offers. 'You can't just leave work' 'Screw work. You need support.'
Do you want Alex to come? Would it help or add stress?

options.text: Yes, come with me. I need you there.
No, stay in New York. I need to focus on family.

new-york-wait-results.title: The Long Wait
story: You decide to wait. Results in 2-3 days. You can always fly then if needed. You text your dad: 'Let me know the second you hear anything. I can be there in 8 hours.'
But waiting is agony. You can't focus on work. Can't focus on anything. Alex comes home and finds you staring at your phone. 'What's wrong?'
You tell them. Alex immediately: 'Book a flight. You should be there.' 'But the results aren't' 'You should be with your family. Results or no results.'

options.text: Take Alex's advice. Book the flight.
Stick with waiting. You'll go if results are bad.

new-york-friend-divorce.title: Crisis Call
story: 11 PM on a Tuesday. Your phone rings. Your best friend from college. 'Sam left me,' they say through tears. 'I came home and half our stuff was gone. No note. No explanation. Just... gone.'
You've known your friend for ten years. You were in their wedding. And now they're having the worst night of their life and you're in a different city.

'I'm catching the train,' you say. 'I'll be there in three hours.' You live in Connecticut, three hours from New York by train. You can be there by 2 AM. But you have an important work presentation at 9 AM tomorrow.
Alex is asleep next to you. You're about to leave in the middle of the night.

options.text: Wake Alex, tell them where you're going, and leave.
Leave a note. Don't wake them.
Stay. Support your friend by phone. You can visit this weekend.
Ask Alex what you should do.

paris-job-ultimatum.title: Return to Office
story: Month three in Paris. Video call with your boss. 'We need to talk about your remote arrangement. The team is struggling without you in person. We need you back in the office. If you can't return within a month, we'll have to let you go.'
Your heart stops. You moved to Paris for Alex. You sacrificed your in-person job to be remote. And now they're taking that away too. You can't commute from Paris to the US. The math doesn't work.
'Can I have some time to think?' 'Two weeks,' your boss says. 'Then we need an answer.' They disconnect. You're sitting in your Paris apartment, alone, facing impossible choices.

options.text: Tell Alex immediately. This affects both of you.
Start job hunting in Paris. Find a solution before panicking Alex.
Ask your boss to reconsider. Fight for remote work.
Accept you'll lose your job. Focus on finding work in Paris.

paris-family-visit-bad-timing.title: Your Parents Want to Visit
story: Your mom calls. 'Dad and I want to visit! See your new life in Paris. We're thinking next month. That weekend you mentioned Alex has the work retreat in Lyon. Perfect timing - we can keep you company!'

Your heart sinks. That's the Riley retreat weekend. The weekend you're already anxious about. The weekend you planned to either go with Alex or spiral alone at home. Adding your parents to that equation feels... complicated.
'Mom, that might not be the best timing...' 'Oh, but the flights are so cheap that weekend! And we haven't seen you in four months. We miss you, sweetie.'

options.text: Say yes. Your parents' visit might be a good distraction.
Say no. You need that weekend to focus on your relationship.
Ask them to come a different weekend instead.
Tell them about the Riley situation. Ask their advice.

paris-friend-moving-to-europe.title: Familiar Face
story: Your college roommate texts: 'Moving to London for work! Can I crash with you in Paris for a week while I apartment hunt? Would love to catch up and see your new life!'

You haven't seen them in two years. You miss having a friend who knows the old you. But the timing is difficult - you're struggling with loneliness, French, Alex's work situation. Do you want a witness to how hard this is?
Also, your apartment is tiny. You and Alex barely fit. Adding a third person for a week means no privacy, no space, constant social performance. But they're your friend. They'd do it for you.

options.text: Say yes enthusiastically. You need familiar company.
Say yes but set boundaries. Three days, not a week.
Suggest they stay in a hostel. You'll hang out but can't host.
Check with Alex first before committing.

money-crisis-shared.title: Financial Reality Check
story: You're looking at your bank account. Rent is due tomorrow. Your freelance payment is late. Alex's paycheck covers their student loans and part of rent, but not everything. You're $800 short.

You have a credit card. You could put rent on it. But you're already carrying a balance. Or you could ask Alex to cover your portion this month. But they've been stressed about money too. Or you could call your parents and borrow it. But that means admitting you're struggling financially in your new life.
This is the unsexy part of adulting. The part where love and partnership meet reality and bills.

options.text: Put it on the credit card. Deal with it later.
Ask Alex to cover you this month. That's what partners do.
Call your parents. Borrow the money.
Look for emergency freelance work. Figure it out yourself.

new-york-accept-promotion-together.title: Power Couple
story: You accept the promotion. You and Alex are now both working intense jobs in New York. The next three months are chaos - late nights, competing deadlines, takeout dinners at 10 PM, exhausted weekends.

But you're equals. You're both building careers. Neither one is sacrificing for the other. When Alex works late, you work late. When you need support, Alex gives it because they understand. You're partners in ambition.
It's not easy. But it's fair. And fairness might matter more than easy.

options.text: Continue with your relationship journey

new-york-reveal-sacrifice.title: The Weight of Unsaid Things
story: 'I got offered a promotion,' you tell Alex one night. 'Senior position. New York office. My dream job.' Alex's eyes light up. 'That's amazing! When do you start?'
'I don't. I turned it down. Two weeks ago.' Alex's face falls. 'What? Why didn't you tell me?' 'Because you're dealing with enough. And I didn't want you to feel guilty.'
'So instead you're resentful.' They're right. You are resentful. You sacrificed your dream job and now you're holding it over Alex's head without them even knowing it was happening.
The fight that follows is ugly. Necessary, but ugly.

options.text: Work through it. This is a communication issue you can fix.
This reveals a bigger problem. You need space.

paris-tell-alex-job.title: Shared Crisis
story: When Alex comes home, you tell them everything. The ultimatum. The two-week deadline. The impossible choice. Alex listens, then pulls you close. 'We'll figure this out. Together.'

'How? I can't commute from Paris to the US.' 'So we find you work in Paris. Or... we consider other options.' 'Like what?' 'Like... maybe I look for work in the US too. If Paris isn't working for you, maybe we go back together.'
You didn't expect that. Alex offering to leave their Paris job. For you. The way you left your in-person job for them.

options.text: Accept the offer. Maybe Paris was a mistake.
Refuse. You'll figure out Paris work. They shouldn't sacrifice their job.
Table it for now. Focus on finding Paris work first.

paris-parents-visit-yes.title: Family Distraction
story: 'Yes! Come!' you say. Maybe having your parents there will keep you from spiraling about Alex and Riley. Maybe showing them Paris will remind you why you made this choice.

Your parents arrive the Friday Alex leaves for Lyon. You spend the weekend being a tour guide. The Eiffel Tower. Notre-Dame. The Louvre. You translate menus and order for them and show them your favorite boulangerie.

You're so busy entertaining them that you barely think about Alex in Lyon with Riley. Well. That's not true. You think about it constantly. But at least you're thinking about it while eating croissants with your mom instead of alone in your apartment.
When Alex comes home Sunday night, your parents meet them for the first time in months. 'You look exhausted,' your mom observes. Alex does look exhausted. And something else. Stressed? Guilty?

options.text: Continue with Lyon aftermath

therapy-first-session-detail.title: Session One
story: Week one of couples therapy. Dr. Martinez's office in Brooklyn. Plants everywhere. You and Alex sit on opposite ends of the couch. Not touching.
'So,' Dr. Martinez begins. 'Tell me why you're here.' Simple question. Complicated answer. You and Alex look at each other. Who starts?
Alex gestures: you go. You take a breath.

options.text: Start with the photo/Riley incident. That's the crisis that brought you here.
Start with the move. The foundation of current stress.
Start with communication. The root issue beneath everything.
Let Alex start. You want to hear their perspective first.

therapy-start-with-crisis.title: The Triggering Event
story: You tell Dr. Martinez about the photo. The anonymous message. Jordan/Riley's constant presence. The fight. The fear. Alex listens, face carefully neutral.

'What I'm hearing,' Dr. Martinez says, 'is that a third party created a crisis in your relationship. But the crisis found fertile ground. If your relationship was secure, an anonymous photo wouldn't have caused this much damage. So what was already there?'
You don't have an answer. Or you do, but you don't want to say it out loud. Alex shifts uncomfortably.

options.text: Admit you've been feeling secondary to Alex's career.
Admit you've been anxious and projecting insecurity.
Ask Alex to answer. What do THEY think was already there?

therapy-start-with-move.title: The Foundation
story: You talk about the move. How hard it's been. How lonely. How you feel like you sacrificed your life to follow Alex's career and now you're drowning in a city that doesn't want you.
Alex's face crumbles. 'I didn't know you felt that way.' 'I didn't want to tell you. You were so happy. I didn't want to ruin it.'
Dr. Martinez leans forward. 'So you've been protecting Alex from your true feelings. And Alex, you haven't been asking. Two people living parallel lives, each one hiding from the other.'

options.text: Commit to radical honesty going forward.
Question if you can actually do radical honesty. It sounds exhausting.

therapy-start-with-communication.title: The Real Problem
story: 'We don't talk,' you say. 'Not really. We ask about surface things. But the real stuff - fears, resentments, needs - we both swallow that. And then it builds until we explode.'
Dr. Martinez nods. 'Communication isn't just talking. It's being willing to be uncomfortable. To say the things that might hurt. To hear the things that might hurt. Can you both do that?'
You and Alex look at each other. Can you?

options.text: Yes. We're ready to be uncomfortable.
Try. We'll try to be uncomfortable.
Honestly? Not sure. That sounds terrifying.

happy-ending-proposal-planning.title: The Question
story: You've made it. Through the fights, the jealousy, the anonymous photos, the hard conversations. You've chosen each other again and again. And now Alex wants to make it permanent.
But HOW they propose matters. Location matters. Timing matters. You've dropped hints over the months about what your dream proposal would look like. Did Alex listen?

options.text: Private moment - just the two of you, intimate and personal
Public gesture - grand, romantic, witnesses to your love
Casual integration - proposal woven into ordinary life

proposal-private.title: Just Us
story: Sunday morning. You're making breakfast in your apartment - now decorated, lived in, truly home. Alex comes up behind you, wraps arms around your waist. 'I need to ask you something.'
You turn. Alex is holding a ring. No grand speech. No performance. Just: 'I want to spend the rest of my life choosing you. Will you marry me?'
It's perfect. Quiet. Private. Exactly what you would have wanted if you'd known what you wanted.

options.text: Say yes immediately. This is everything.
Say yes but cry first. You need a moment.
Make a joke. 'About time.' Then say yes.

proposal-public.title: Grand Gesture
story: Alex takes you to the Brooklyn Bridge at sunset. There are photographers. Friends hiding nearby. When you get to the middle of the bridge, they're all there. A setup. A production.
Part of you loves it - the romance, the effort, the declaration. Part of you feels uncomfortable - all these people watching, the pressure to react perfectly, the performance of intimacy.
Alex drops to one knee. Everyone has their phones out. This will be on social media within minutes. 'Will you marry me?'

options.text: Say yes. Get swept up in the romance of it all.
Say yes but feel weird about the public nature.

proposal-casual.title: Ordinary Magic
story: You're grocery shopping. Arguing about whether to get the expensive cheese or the cheap cheese. Alex says, 'We're going to be having this argument for the rest of our lives, you know.'
'Probably,' you agree. 'Good thing I like arguing with you.' 'Good thing I like you.' Alex pauses. 'Actually... will you marry me?'
Between the dairy aisle and the checkout line. No ring visible. No preparation. Just a question that feels like the most natural thing in the world.

options.text: Say yes in the grocery store. Perfect is overrated.
Ask if they're serious or joking first.

tragic-ending-who-leaves.title: The End Approaching
story: You've reached the point of no return. The relationship is ending. You both know it. The only question now is logistics. Who leaves? Who stays? How do you untangle a life you built together?
The apartment lease is in both your names. Your stuff is mixed together. Your lives are entwined in a thousand small ways. This is going to hurt.

options.text: You'll leave. This was Alex's city first.
Ask Alex to leave. You need the familiar space to heal.
Neither of you leaves yet. Figure out logistics slowly.
Both leave. Fresh start for both of you.

tragic-you-leave.title: Packing Your Life
story: You pack. Alex tries to help. You don't want their help. Every item you put in a box is a memory you're leaving behind. The coffee maker you bought together. Books with both your names in them. That weird lamp from IKEA that took four hours to assemble.
Alex sits on the couch, watching. 'I'm sorry,' they say. For the hundredth time. You don't respond. There's nothing left to say that hasn't been said a hundred times already.
The last box is packed. Your Uber is coming. This is it.

options.text: Hug Alex goodbye. End with kindness even if you're ending.
Leave without ceremony. Clean break is better.
One last conversation. Try to explain what went wrong.

bittersweet-staying-friends.title: Redefining Love
story: Six months after the breakup. You and Alex meet for coffee. It's the first time you've seen each other since you divided up the furniture. Awkward at first. Then easier than you expected.

You talk about your lives now. Alex is seeing someone new. You're happy for them. Genuinely happy, which surprises you. You're seeing someone too. You show Alex a picture. 'They're cute,' Alex says. 'They are,' you agree.
The romantic love is gone. But there's still love. Different love. Softer love. The kind that wants the other person to be happy even if it's not with you.

options.text: Commit to being friends. Real friends. This is your new chapter.
Stay friendly but distant. Some things are better left in the past.
Realize you're not over them yet. This was a mistake.

reconciliation-rebuilding-trust.title: One Day at a Time
story: Trust, once broken, doesn't rebuild overnight. Dr. Martinez warned you. Healing is slow. Nonlinear. Some days you feel secure. Other days you spiral.
Today is a spiral day. Alex is ten minutes late coming home. Your brain goes: late means something bad means betrayal means it's happening again. You know this is irrational. You spiral anyway.
Alex comes through the door. 'Sorry, the subway was delayed.' Just the subway. Not a conspiracy. Just trains.

options.text: Tell Alex you were spiraling. Vulnerability is part of healing.
Keep the spiral to yourself. Work through it internally.
Use the tools from therapy. Check the facts. Ground yourself.

wedding-planning-style.title: The Wedding
story: You're engaged. The hard part is over, right? Wrong. Now you have to plan a wedding. And you and Alex have very different ideas about what that should look like.
Alex wants big - family, friends, celebration, the works. You want intimate - close friends only, simple ceremony, nothing flashy. Or maybe it's reversed. Either way, you don't agree.
Your first fight as an engaged couple is about wedding venues.

options.text: Compromise. Medium wedding. Some family, some friends.
Elope. Skip the drama entirely.
Let Alex plan it. Their vision matters more.
Long engagement. Figure it out slowly.

therapy-breakthrough-moment.title: The Breakthrough
story: Month four of therapy. You're in session. Talking about the same patterns you've talked about for months. Suddenly Dr. Martinez stops you.
'Do you hear what you just did?' You don't. Alex doesn't. 'You both just communicated a need, listened to each other, and found compromise. In real time. Without fighting. That's growth.'
You and Alex look at each other. We did? We did. Holy shit, we did.
It's a small moment. But it's everything. You're actually getting better at this.

options.text: Celebrate the breakthrough. Acknowledge the progress.
Be cautious. One good moment doesn't mean you're fixed.
Ask if you're ready to reduce therapy frequency.

future-together-location.title: Where Do We Go From Here?
story: You've made it through the crisis. You're together. You're committed. But practical question: where do you actually want to build your life?
New York/Paris was never the forever plan. It was the Alex's job plan. But now you're both here, both established. Do you stay? Go back home? Try somewhere new entirely?
This is the rest of your life you're planning. No pressure.

options.text: Stay here. You've built a life. Why start over?
Move back home. Be near family and old friends.
New city entirely. Fresh start together.
Wherever we both have good job opportunities.

breakup-conversation-detail.title: The Words
story: You're sitting across from each other. Someone has to say it. Someone has to make it real. You've been dancing around it for weeks. Maybe months. But now it's time.
Who says it first matters. It's not fair, but it's true. The person who says 'I think we should break up' becomes the bad guy in the story you tell yourself later.

options.text: You say it. 'I think we need to break up.'
Wait for Alex to say it. They're thinking it too.
Say it together. 'I think we both know...'
One last attempt. 'Unless... is there any way to fix this?'

therapy-graduation.title: Graduation
story: Dr. Martinez smiles. 'I think you're ready. You don't need me anymore. You have the tools. You've done the work. You're good.'
It's your last therapy session. You're graduating couples counseling. Which sounds either triumphant or terrifying depending on how you look at it.
'What if we backslide?' you ask. 'Then you come back,' Dr. Martinez says simply. 'This isn't pass/fail. It's just... you're ready to try without training wheels.'

options.text: Feel confident. You've got this.
Feel nervous. What if you forget everything you learned?
Schedule a follow-up in three months. Just in case.

anniversary-of-move.title: One Year Later
story: It's been exactly one year since you moved here. One year since you packed your entire life into boxes and followed Alex to a new city. One year of growth, pain, fights, love, and learning.
Alex remembers. Brings home flowers. 'Happy anniversary. We made it.' You made it. Through everything. You're still here. Still together. Still choosing each other.
How do you want to mark this milestone?

options.text: Go out. Celebrate big. You earned this.
Stay in. Quiet reflection. Remember how far you've come.
Recreate your first date. Full circle moment.

final-reflection.title: Looking Back
story: Years later, you're asked what made your relationship work. Or not work. Depending on which ending you got. You think about all the choices. All the moments. All the times you could have gone left instead of right.
What was the thing that mattered most? The thing that determined your fate?

options.text: Communication. We learned to actually talk to each other.
Trust. We chose to trust even when it was scary.
Timing. Sometimes love isn't enough if the timing is wrong.
Self-awareness. We realized we wanted different things.
